Although the violence is eventually contained, Rose is troubled by her son's cold behavior. The story is gripping and intense.

**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam is a chubby, talkative boy who admires his sophisticated cousin, Lisa, from the wealthy side of the family. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her regain her balance, leading both of them to a better understanding of reality and the importance of family. While the pace can be slow at times, the gentle humor and the growing bond between the two teenagers are well portrayed. This story appeals to both boys and girls, which is quite rare.

**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, vividly capturing his New Zealand setting through the eyes of Robbie, a likable first-person narrator. Robbie takes a job gardening for an elderly man named Stanley, initially finding him interesting but later disturbing. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them, the story takes a thrilling turn while still providing deep insights into character and relationships. It is an unusual and compelling read.

**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a painful and sad story that explores the troubled relationships and difficult school life of a boy named Mick. The narrative skillfully combines flashbacks, letters from a teacher to a friend, and Mick's own notes. Mick learns to cope with the negative expectations of others and his low self-esteem through his role in a school play and the support of a caring first-year teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a deeply emotional read, especially towards the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are using weightlessness to test their theories. From the outside, the aircraft looked like any other, but it was actually a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964. The 13 students from Europe and America who boarded were about to experience an incredible flight. Inside, the plane resembled a long white tunnel with few windows and lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, leaving only a few at the back where the nervous young scientists sat.

For a year, these students had competed to take part in this flight, which was organized by the European Space Agency. They had to propose creative experiments to be conducted in weightlessness. Those with the best ideas earned a spot on this unique flight, which felt like the most extraordinary roller-coaster ride.

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that mimicked a giant bird soaring upwards before diving back down. The goal was to create moments of weightlessness at the top of each curve. When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the aircraft would rise higher due to its momentum before gravity pulled it back down. During the brief moments of weightlessness, the students would feel as if they were closer to the moon than to Earth.

The flight took off smoothly, but any thoughts of a regular passenger flight vanished when the pilot put the plane into a steep climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies were thrown around the cabin. Then, the engines stopped, and we quickly transitioned to weightlessness. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. Moving became confusing; directions like left, right, up, or down lost their meaning. Only gravity helps us understand where we are.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its dive. The return of gravity was sudden, causing some students to land hard. After completing the first curve, some students felt uneasy about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves provided ten minutes of "space time" for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to find out how cats always land on their feet. They released a device they built to investigate this, and one student managed to flip it over using a remote control. 

However, during the next curve, another student accidentally landed on the device, nearly damaging it. Meanwhile, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joints behave without gravity, which could help in building future space stations. Another group from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They hoped that once perfected, these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind.

After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not nausea. This experience would stay with us for a long time. One student said, "It was unforgettable. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 

I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer, which was actually winter there, so I had nine consecutive winters. I enjoyed this because I like winter. My parents had the idea of buying a small piece of land for my siblings and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then you can have it.” The goal was for us to always have a connection to New Zealand, which is a lovely thought since my father grew up there. They found a plot of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was suitable for planting trees. I have always been passionate about land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me, and I was eager to start. My family became enthusiastic as we progressed. I began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it was one of those rainy winters. It rained a lot, almost every day we were planting. It seems strange to remember that time as very happy since I was often wet and cold. Each morning was a challenge: getting ready for the next planting session. I would come out of the Land Rover, still warm and dry, but then face the rain, with my jacket damp from the previous day, my boots soaked, and my hands struggling with slippery laces. “The brain starts to take over, allowing for all sorts of strange thoughts and reflections about life.” 

In that first year, I had an experienced tree-planter working with me, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck, filling it with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it’s heavy, and only when it gets lighter does it become easier. The hardest part of the job was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then set up three poles in a straight line. These poles guide your planting. Once you are aligned, you plant all the way down the line, turn around, and come back. I enjoy hard physical work, and it kept me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically, finding a rhythm and using the fewest spade strokes needed to dig the hole. 

This rhythm is something everyone talks about, and it’s true for many farming jobs. You train your body to perform a series of standard moves, making the task much easier. You develop a regular process: taking the tree from the bag, digging a hole, placing it in the ground, stamping it down, and moving on. Mentally, it’s fascinating. My mind would wander, allowing me to think about the natural world and our place in it. Many of my thoughts about these topics began during that time.

I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and have watched the trees grow, which is very satisfying since I planted them and feel a connection to their success. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such headlines make me anxious. Fortunately, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.

I should add that I took a break from teaching and returned to New Zealand in 1984, completely alone for three months. During that time, I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I would write; in the afternoons, I would prune the trees, and in the evenings, I would do research. My connection to that area remains very strong. In many ways, it is the place I feel most connected to, representing the bond between people and the earth—a powerful connection.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have run an open farm in Somerset for six years, known for caring for orphaned animals. However, the strange noise coming from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—caught my attention. I looked inside and found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were covered in fleas, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early lives underground. If they become orphaned, they often starve and are never found. 

These three cubs were brought to me by builders who accidentally disturbed their sett while laying drain pipes. Their mother was found dead, with her babies still suckling. Although the cubs were healthy, they were cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove for warmth. I named the two females Primrose and Bluebell, and the male Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to mimic their mother’s licking, which helped them relieve themselves. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started moving around, though a bit unsteadily. They were happy together, with a heated pad as a substitute for their mother.

However, three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, even though he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize its importance. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet's examination showed that he had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding animals, it’s crucial not to let them drink too quickly, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, especially for such a small cub. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other two.

Then, six days later, a local farmer, who had heard about my cubs, came to see me. He had found another male cub abandoned by its mother behind some silage bags. He knew she wouldn’t return, as the area had been disturbed, and the cub was cold and hungry. I named him Willow II. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon discovered why his mother had left him; he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day.

By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to chew and eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more variety. At nearly five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Normally, badgers eat 60% earthworms, along with beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and plant roots. My badgers were better off than others that year, as the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms.

By August, my badgers had started to become nocturnal, going for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they would get excited, fluff up their fur, and chase each other’s tails. As "human badgers," we joined in their fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and ended up with colorful bruises.

During two late-night walks in a dry spell, I noticed other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territory to find food, even though badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive towards others. We were warned that they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so positive that we started a campaign to build a sett for them on the farm. With help from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate that faced their usual walking path. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside.

As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became more interested in the tunnels and bedding than in walking. The building costs were higher than we expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of the project, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a proper home.

One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I quietly returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. Nowadays, I don’t walk with them as often, especially since they don’t fully wake up until midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she has joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to greet me before rushing off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

**In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, during his time, one of his most important achievements was mapping the "variations of the compass" using calculations from his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called "declination," refer to the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Understanding declination was crucial for sailors to correct their compasses and navigate accurately.

Halley, one of only two men in England paid for scientific research at that time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip was cut short due to crew issues, but he later sailed to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these journeys, he published a chart in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. More advanced charts based on his work helped sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made them less accurate.

Dr. Clark, a passionate sailor, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, with support from Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during his two years at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley led a remarkable life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not only an astronomer but also researched geophysics. While serving as Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and pursued other interests."

During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton on his work, *Principia Mathematica*, which is fundamental to classical physics. Dr. Clark believes that recreating Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements similar to Halley's but with much more accurate instruments. These measurements are necessary because the Earth's magnetic field is constantly changing. The data collected will help improve the current mathematical model of the Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field.

"It is common to measure the strength but not the direction of the magnetic field," Dr. Clark explains. "You need to know true north to measure direction. On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites for this." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments, and a Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean, and having ground-based measurements will be useful for comparison.

Halley's Atlantic journey was significant as it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he became the first civilian naval captain to pursue the study of declination. Does Dr. Clark have the qualifications to succeed in his voyage? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has already sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.

Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? "I am willing to dedicate eight months to this, so some might see me as obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the critical eyes of the peahens. This behavior raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: how could birds develop such extravagant features in a world where survival is often about being strong or fast? How do they manage to thrive with such a burden?

Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade, a century after Darwin's death, to find answers. Darwin believed that living beings evolved through natural selection, meaning that the individuals best suited to their environment are more likely to survive and reproduce. Typically, this would mean that the strongest or smartest individuals would thrive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, leading Darwin to propose a different idea called "sexual selection." He suggested that females are attracted to beauty for its own sake.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens preferred males with the most impressive tails, there must be a deeper reason behind this choice. According to Wallace, the tail was not just for show; it indicated some other quality that contributed to survival.

Today, researchers still debate these ideas. Studying the natural behavior of peafowl is challenging, but the 200 birds at Whipsnade, which live in a semi-wild environment and are accustomed to humans, provide a unique opportunity for research. Petrie and her team are focusing on two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the most extravagant tails? And do these males possess any additional qualities that make them better mates, as Wallace suggested, or is it just about appearance, as Darwin thought?

Observations show that the peahens do seem to prefer the males with the most eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. Males with more eye-spots attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University proposed that showy male birds might be less likely to have parasites, and their bright feathers could signal their health. There is some evidence for this in other bird species, but Petrie and her team have not yet been able to study the internal health of the peacocks at Whipsnade.

This year, Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive males with those of less attractive ones. Are the young of the attractive males healthier and growing faster? If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is based on practical benefits.

There is also an interesting theory from mathematician and biologist R.A. Fisher, known as "Fisher's Runaway." This theory suggests that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that trait, and her daughters will inherit her preference for long tails. Over generations, this could lead to males with increasingly long tails, reinforcing the idea that females are selecting for beauty.

In conclusion, this ongoing research may ultimately support both Darwin's and Wallace's theories, showing that beauty can play a significant role in mate selection.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix traditional and modern elements. He has applied this idea in his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London showcases many beautiful yachts filled with the latest technology. Most of these boats are based on a new hull design that emerged 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat rests quietly in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although it was designed last year, it looks like it is 100 years old, which might make you think its owner is a romantic. I might be, but I’m not sure.

My boat combines the charm of classic design with the benefits of modern technology. However, while technology is essential in today’s boat design and building, it often separates sailors from the true challenges of life at sea. Many sailors seek to reconnect with these challenges by going to sea. I’m not saying that sailors should face every hardship. I believe it’s important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Dealing with a flapping sail is part of being a sailor.

Why should we give up common sense and move our steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a less secure spot near the front? Unfortunately, this change often results in a cabin that resembles a luxury cruise ship, with a bed larger than one at home. To me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating house.

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner noted that it had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over the years, I learned how true that was. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and most enjoyable boat I ever sailed.

However, classic boats require a lot of maintenance, and when I injured my back, I realized I could no longer care for Hirta. I looked for a younger boat but found none that met my needs, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett use computer design programs, Irens first sketched the boat on a paper napkin before moving to the computer. After creating a model, just like traditional boatyards did, we refined the design together. The final version was perfect.

The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She has a timeless look, sails beautifully, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, creates a peaceful atmosphere. This may be because she was designed solely as a sailing boat, without considering any furniture. This traditional approach works well. In her calm presence, she proves that you don’t need to follow trends to find happiness, and sometimes it’s wise to learn from history. Built with timber treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. This means she has the advantages of a fiberglass boat while still looking, feeling, and sailing like a classic.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was excited to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to unwind. My room in the large 18th-century house was extremely comfortable, and I felt relaxed right away. On the first day, I did nothing but sleep. Starting on the second day, I joined body conditioning classes and tried as many activities as I could, like yoga and stretching. The instructors were very skilled, and I was amazed at how flexible I became during the week. They offer a wide range of treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment, which lasts an hour, truly makes you feel rejuvenated. The staff in the treatment rooms were friendly, kind, and professional. The atmosphere was lively and positive. Henlow is planning to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. Bicycles are available for riding around the grounds. If you prefer a quieter time and the weather is nice, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I definitely want to return. This is the ideal getaway for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The peaceful atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I walked up the grand staircase to the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can avoid talking to others if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone receives a medical check-up, including an examination of weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt a bit strange since I am healthy. However, I was impressed that a shoulder issue found during the check-up was quickly addressed by the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and individual sessions. Each guest follows a specific diet. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry enough to get a bad headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you’re not on a light diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is delicious and well-presented. You receive a massage or water therapy every other day, and extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*

**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm and doesn’t pretend to be. It’s a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you’re counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food, which includes rich sauces and creamy desserts made by a French chef. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, so I could work off some of the delicious food. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A major attraction is the sports injury clinic. I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside nearby.  
*Beverly D'Silva*

**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-rated restaurant, serves amazing dishes. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu because there were so many options. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed feeling very happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other journalists who would write about fitness assessments and beauty treatments. Cliveden has all these options if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It’s the best because it’s the most delicious I’ve ever had, but it’s also the worst because it has 360 calories, which can be a setback if you’re trying to lose weight. You’ve been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose a relaxing oil blend and fell asleep twice during the treatment. I returned to my room and had the best night’s sleep in years. The facilities are modern and well-organized, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, making it easy to book appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a diverse group, including football teams, mothers and daughters, friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed significant differences; genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This suggests that the traits that make us human are a recent development in our evolutionary history. Our ability to create art and other unique human characteristics likely come from just a small number of our genes. This is a heavy responsibility for such a limited set of genes. 

Recent studies of animal behavior have shown that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree rather than kind. For instance, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools; chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a basic form of language, using different sounds to warn of predators like leopards, eagles, and snakes. This means that aside from art, there are few clear differences between humans and animals.

However, if human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it is curious that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. We only have clear evidence of human art, such as cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments, starting around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we argue that our recent artistic achievements set us apart, we must consider how our art differs from that of animals. Three common claims are made: human art is non-utilitarian, it is created for aesthetic pleasure, and it is learned rather than instinctive. 

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." A biologist might interpret this to mean that human art does not help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. While some human art serves a purpose in communication, it is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong has clear functions, such as defending territory or attracting mates, which help transmit their genes. By this standard, human art does seem different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during mating season, suggesting they do not sing just for beauty. Again, this makes human art seem unique.

The third claim is that human art is learned rather than instinctive. Different human groups have distinct art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are easily recognizable. However, these styles are not genetically inherited. In contrast, some bird species are born with the ability to sing their specific songs, even if they have never heard them before. 

The role of learning in human art is evident in how quickly our art styles change. For instance, geese have honked the same way for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a twentieth-century painting is more recent than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify the time and artist of a painting they have not seen before. However, even experts might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day, seemingly for his own enjoyment, and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot claim.

These chimpanzee paintings challenge the distinctions between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the paintings by these apes did not serve a practical purpose; they were created for the satisfaction of the painter. One might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend to communicate through their work, while the apes did not care about sharing their paintings. However, this argument is not entirely convincing, as some famous human artworks were also created for personal satisfaction rather than communication.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth and also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left, and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and squinting eyes, searching for the unknown. Nowadays, such characters are rare in both fiction and real life. That was my belief until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's adventure involved leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, which means "once entered, you never come out." Locals call it the Desert of Death. He shared the dangers and excitement of this incredible journey from the comfort of his home. His team included four Britons (one was a medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone and threatened the success of the expedition.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the harshest deserts in the world, and Blackmore has written a captivating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to find purpose in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t return since no one had ever completed that route; we were going into it without any knowledge."

In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and Blackmore described the desert as "kind." However, anyone reading his remarkable story would question this description. The team faced extreme hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and the loss of part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we avoided the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we didn’t face challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. Climbing the high dunes was torture for us and the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."

"What motivated me most was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very afraid of my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to start now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was toned, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the struggle it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share. By that measure, the desert doesn’t compare."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We were motivated by a sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to fit into the sameness of modern life."

**Text: 'Rediscovering Manual Labor'**

Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy the benefits of doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it provides us with amazing devices that simplify our lives and give us more free time. However, this reliance on technology has led us to believe that it is essential, which may not be true. For example, using our hands for tasks does not harm the environment, unlike some gadgets.

After a frustrating experience with a broken word processor, which cost a lot to fix, Susan began to question whether gadgets are really worth the money and hassle. She started to let her household technology fade away as it broke down. This made her think about what "time" technology actually gives us. Does it just allow us to take on more activities that require even more gadgets? If that’s the case, it seems like a clever marketing trick.

When her broken device started making strange noises, even after being unplugged, she decided to leave it outside, where it now sits quietly. Susan enjoys not being tied to noisy machines and prefers to take her time with her sewing. She has always been a bit nervous around electric sewing machines, which can be dangerous.

While there are some gadgets she appreciates, like her washing machine, she has found joy in living without others. For instance, after feeling that they were spending too much time in front of the television, she returned their rented color TV and switched back to a small black-and-white one. This change has encouraged them to spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies.

One of her hobbies is sewing, and she has stopped using her old sewing machine, which now serves as a plant table. Although she cannot afford to replace it, she has started sewing by hand. Many people believe they cannot live without their gadgets, but Susan feels differently. She thinks about how past generations endured hard work without modern conveniences.

Computers have made our lives easier by performing complex tasks quickly and providing entertainment. However, Susan finds that hand sewing is not boring at all. In fact, it allows her to listen to the radio or talk with family while she works. If the task is simple, she can even watch her favorite TV shows without feeling guilty, as she is also being productive.

Sewing by hand gives her a comforting feeling, especially when she sits by the fire with a cup of tea. She used to think that women who sewed intricate items by hand had a difficult life, but now she appreciates the calming nature of crafting. She finds satisfaction in watching her work improve and enjoys the slower pace of life that comes with it.

Additionally, she has taken back control of her kitchen, enjoying the simple act of washing dishes while daydreaming. This reflection has led her to reconsider the need for various appliances in her home. She wonders if they really need a freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. In fact, she realizes they could save a lot of money by living without electric lights!

Text: 'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems like a man in a hurry. When I arrive at his workshop, located under a railway arch in East London, he greets me with a quick handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It’s hard to tell if he is truly brusque or just hiding his shyness. However, looking around the workshop, it’s clear that Hurst is busy, with good reason to not waste any time. The space is filled with unfinished furniture and wooden planks in a variety of natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built a strong reputation. His order book is always full for months ahead, even though he doesn’t actively promote himself. People know that if you want a quality cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the one to contact. 

Finding a furniture-maker is not difficult, as the craft is thriving in the countryside. However, it is harder to find a cabinet-maker who focuses on creating beautifully crafted furniture with clean, simple designs. "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many call themselves furniture-makers," Hurst says with a hint of disappointment. As a craftsman with high standards, he often feels let down by modern furniture. "I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people accept." His pursuit of perfection is clearly a key part of his success, along with his talent. Hurst is confident about his skills. "I have a huge natural ability," he states seriously. "I have always been good at making things." If it weren’t for his modesty towards the end of our conversation, I would have thought he was completely serious.

Hurst is self-taught. So how did he learn his craft? "I asked the right questions and picked it all up," he says casually. Most of his work comes from private clients. "I used to do commercial work for companies, but it was soul-destroying." Some clients return to him repeatedly. "You end up doing their whole house. That is very satisfying." However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. "The most frustrating clients are those who don’t know what they want, and then change their minds too late. My favorite clients are the exacting ones." 

While Hurst has every reason to be proud, he is also generous in praising others when it’s deserved. With a sudden touch of modesty, he says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other craftsmen. After all, I wasn’t trained at Parnham," which is a top furniture design college. However, he is critical of those craftsmen who "try to be artists and take a year to make one piece." He also has little patience for degree shows, where students showcase their work while trying to make fashion statements. "That can be pretentious. A piece of furniture should be practical and usable." 

Hurst may be confident and direct, but he is not pretentious. His final words show a refreshing down-to-earth attitude towards his work and a humility that contrasts with his earlier confidence. "After all, I am only making furniture," he says as I leave.'

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping, which suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need so much sleep. There are three main theories.

The first and most popular theory suggests that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It argues that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and restore our energy.

The second theory focuses on the benefits of sleep for learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and without it, we would struggle to learn effectively.

The third theory is about energy. It suggests that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most people have their own quirks and peculiarities. For example, someone might enjoy entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing passionate letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity is a way of expressing our individuality.

Inside us, there is often a struggle between two opposing forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism represents our desire to be unique, while conformity represents our need to fit in. For many, the desire to be accepted and liked by others is stronger than the desire to stand out and be different.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests, which others might see as strange. The key idea here is 'common.' They seek others who understand their oddities, as being part of a group can be comforting.

Most of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be ourselves. Even when we follow the crowd, we may feel the need to assert our individuality. For instance, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," or a new acquaintance might declare, "You must take me as you find me. I don't stand on ceremony."

At any moment, we can choose to embrace our individuality. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, the American singer, once said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then pursue it passionately—don't back down and don't give up—you will confuse many people." However, this self-assertion is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. 

When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, they are not being eccentric. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they may be considered eccentric. The key aspect of eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are.

True eccentrics are not concerned with public opinion; they act according to their true selves. This sets them apart from enthusiasts, practical jokers, clever criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses, who are all aware of society. Eccentrics, on the other hand, live their lives freely, regardless of societal expectations.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the opportunity to meet many important figures in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She has been central to environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from various environmental movements into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, I found that she helped me understand these complex topics better than anyone else. Choosing her book was more difficult. I considered "Only One Earth" and "Progress for a Small Planet," but I believe "The Home of Man" is her most significant work. It discusses the rapid growth of cities while addressing the larger themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now refer to as "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of guano in the sun. This book beautifully explains the fascinating world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony transforms from chaos into a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a distinguished behaviorist who aimed to make his research accessible to everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion resulted in a book that appeals to anyone who loves nature. Ennion's paintings, created from years of observing birds, vividly show how one gull can be aggressive while another is submissive. This is the work of a true field naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a fulfilling career in conservation, but it also deepened my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my world brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Many believe humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, viewing all living beings as a family, intertwined and inseparable. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I discovered "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images captivated me. I already owned other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds, which inspired me to start sketching them. However, "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a section on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and stunning images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new possibilities for my future.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?** We asked five major British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here’s what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers; they are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually more accepting of bad reviews. They believe that any mention in the press can help sales, as readers will want to form their own opinions. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own views on a book since they often read it first.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers have different needs when it comes to book reviews. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, ideally in a positive way. Book reviews today are more varied and accessible than they were 40 years ago, but there is still a tendency to overlook paperbacks, which many people read. Weekly summaries of books are often not enough, and even original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. However, publishers should not complain too much. Like readers and writers, they need reviews, which are a cost-effective way to promote a book and its author. A good review from a trusted source can significantly boost sales, especially if there are multiple reviews.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing; without them, we would struggle. Our books are usually not by well-known authors, and we rarely advertise, so we rely on literary editors to give our books space. Positive reviews are much more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers often say they care more about the length of reviews than their content. The impact of reviews on sales is complex. Good reviews can launch a book and a career, but they need to be supported by other factors like word-of-mouth recommendations and effective marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the U.S., it’s straightforward: a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, booksellers often ignore reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of great reviews for a good writer to gain readers. Interestingly, some poorly received books or those without reviews can still sell very well. The situation is unpredictable, although non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than on the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they actually lead to sales? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it didn’t sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the reviewer’s name matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers praised a book, people paid attention. Today, it can also be the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages buyers to visit the bookstore.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, this skill is still practiced in the workshop of Graham Smith, one of the few artisans in the country who creates hand-cut weathervanes. Graham designs each piece to meet the specific needs of his customers. "This way, I can create a unique, personalized item," he says. Many of his customers are women looking for special gifts for their husbands, wanting something that reflects their partner's business or hobbies.

Graham's work is quite different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. In fact, the first weathervane he made featured a witch on a broomstick, which surprised his wife. Friends admired it and soon asked him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that the subjects I could use were endless," he explains. This realization led him to focus on his weathervane business.

Before starting this venture, Graham trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Five years ago, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles: she became the main breadwinner while he took care of their children and built the business. He has no regrets about this change. "My previous job lacked creativity, but this work is exciting and artistic," he shares. "I really enjoy the design process."

Graham has now developed over 100 original designs. He pays great attention to detail and always seeks customer approval for the silhouette design before he begins cutting. He also keeps a selection of traditional designs available, as they remain popular alongside his unique creations. "People are drawn to handmade items," he notes. "They appreciate the chance to own something a bit different."

Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to maintain its rural craft nature. "I have found my niche in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I find great satisfaction in transforming a simple shape into something almost lifelike," he explains. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by indicating changes in wind direction." Nowadays, as more people move to rural areas, they want to add a special touch to their homes, which has benefited crafts like his.

Graham's business has grown, and he now supplies flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world, with particular interest from buyers in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans faced many challenges. His film project, *Life and Limb*, which he had worked on for months, suddenly fell apart. He felt disappointed and worried because it had been two years since he earned any money, and he was struggling to keep his bank manager calm. A sensible person in his situation would have found a job, perhaps returning to television. Instead, Evans made a surprising choice: he bought a ticket to America to spend three months researching his first novel.

Although this decision seemed impulsive, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. He had met a farrier in Dartmoor who told him about a gentle horse that unexpectedly became aggressive. The horse's owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people were called "horse whisperers," and Evans was intrigued. Initially, he planned to write a screenplay, but after losing hope in the film industry, he decided to write a book instead.

During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing others, but I felt very alone and worried about my life falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, unsure how to support my family, and questioning if it was all a mistake."

By the end of August, after returning home and writing the first half of the book, he felt the pressure from his bank manager. He needed to know if it was worth continuing. He bravely showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for an estimate, he suggested Evans might receive $30,000 as an advance. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer*, with at least two more months of work ahead. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with the summary, to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down an initial offer of $75,000. "You what?" Evans replied, surprised. The agent explained, "It's OK, I just feel something big is happening."

What happened next is now part of publishing history. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were in shock. We had never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans said. They also did not send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for the film rights. "My UK agent wisely involved an American agent, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief." 

As they agreed on this amount, the studios each wanted to present their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four prominent filmmakers called one after another, eager to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel. 

Evans shared this story with me over coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been like a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very challenging, and I don't want to become just another employee for these people I like who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then hear, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll bring in someone else now.'"

He plans to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new funding for *Life and Limb*, but he was uncertain if he wanted to pursue that project. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to the world of chess. Chess has become increasingly a game for younger players. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game impressively, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now 49 years old, he is out of practice and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 

The game of chess has changed significantly in the last two decades. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Today, winning is the main goal for chess players. In international chess, a player’s mental strength and endurance are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high, with a chess clock ensuring players make their moves in a set time. If they fail to do so, they lose immediately. Now, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks, increasing the pressure on players. 

In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30. The way chess is played has also evolved. Much preparation now happens off the board, including psychological strategies. Players must prepare thoroughly before matches, especially with the rise of computer databases that can store millions of chess games. These tools allow players to analyze their opponents' past games and find weaknesses. 

Today, there are more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes worldwide. Success in chess requires both mental and physical effort, as a single game can last up to eight hours. During this time, players must maintain focus, as even a small mistake can lead to losing. The presence of the chess clock adds to the stress, often leading to frantic moments where players must make quick moves or risk losing. 

At the highest level, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction and relief from stress. However, one victory is not enough to win a tournament; players must be ready for the next challenge. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games played every day, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in 1984 had to be stopped after several months due to exhaustion, with Karpov losing significant weight.

Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game puzzling. However, it also adds to his legacy. If he has returned for financial reasons, he will likely succeed, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some of the new British talent, from poets to pop stars, who are rising to fame.

**A**  
Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." What is remarkable about Nick is that before writing *Peaches*, he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he explains. "It's set in a car, which I probably wouldn't do now because I understand the challenges involved. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After completing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my work to be performed, not just read, because of its rhythm and rhyme," he says. "For the first time, I was around people who thought like me. It was a very enjoyable and stimulating environment."

**B**  
Simon Pegg, 28, has made significant progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just completed a demanding tour with comedian Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard, even during his time at university, where he practiced his comedy skills in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a traditional actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his collaboration with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.

**C**  
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, gained public attention as the lead in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he smiles. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position for someone who has just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear that such success was likely. Encouraged by his mother, he moved from leading roles in school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he spent four years. "I was basically using acting as an excuse to avoid homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to pursue it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for doing good work."

**D**  
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is different from mine," he says. "They want a hit, but for me, if just two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel discouraged. Just when I was about to give up, I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were moments when I felt very down, and I had been in some terrible bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E**  
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won more awards and honors than many people twice his age. He is well-known in the poetry community, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but became disillusioned with education later. "I chose not to go to university, but I realized I needed to after getting bored stuffing envelopes at a theater." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a bold step. "My poetry has a structure, which limits the chance of making mistakes. A novel can be any length, so there are more opportunities for errors. My main goal is to avoid falling into a routine where I just produce work without caring about its quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this quirky novel, believes she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she wants to avoid the wrong crowd. At 31, she is an art student who loves historical romances and is searching for Mr. Right, worried that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances. Despite her concerns, she remains hopeful, which ultimately helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a style reminiscent of early silent films, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It offers a humorous perspective on radio, seen through the eyes of a clever but timid child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station quickly features a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town setting allows the author to showcase his dry humor and subtle writing style, taking readers back to the simpler times of the 1940s and 1950s, filled with dime stores, vintage cars, and, of course, radio.

C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to chat with his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls for a beautiful Russian poetess, he shares his feelings with his wife's ex-husband. The poetess writes poor poetry, which bothers Richard, and she is also seeking his help for her wrongly imprisoned brother. However, the way the author unravels these issues is even more interesting. He moves the story forward with a strong sense of humor and carefully examines relationships, making it a highly enjoyable and clever read.

D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become intertwined in each other's lives for the next twenty-five years. At the beginning of this lengthy novel, James Hudson, a mysterious American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that they both loved a woman who was killed years earlier. The story includes themes of murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, all written well. This book allows readers to deeply connect with the characters and become fully engaged in their lives.

E. This touching and funny story, written by a top American author, follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake. To make amends, he becomes a father figure to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor, dealing with the challenges of family life. The story explores a range of emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that perfectly balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four academic writers discuss international voluntary work. 

A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a significant direct contribution to development. While they may help build homes or schools, they often pay a large fee to participate in this work. This money, if given directly to a local community, could pay for more labor than the volunteer could provide. This is particularly true for gap year volunteers, who usually have little technical skill or professional experience. Therefore, many studies raise the question of whether gap year volunteering is mainly driven by a genuine desire to help the local community or if young people are more interested in gaining experience that will benefit their careers. However, these projects can help develop individuals who may act ethically in support of those who are less fortunate in their future careers.

B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, increased participation in global issues through civic organizations, and the growth of international social networks among everyday people. In this way, the overall benefits can be greater than the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and host communities, and contributing to the global good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may provide them with a broader perspective and career advantages, but it will not significantly help those communities that lack access to international volunteer opportunities. Volunteers may continue to benefit personally while using host organizations and communities to advance their own goals.

C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving charity, where wealthy Westerners seek personal development. At its best, it can provide benefits to both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for the exchange of skills, knowledge, and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and foster a lifelong commitment to addressing issues of inequality, poverty, and unsustainable development.

D. Volunteer tourism aligns with the growing trend of individuals wanting to help others. These limited efforts, aimed at making a small difference, can seem positive, especially in a climate that is skeptical of large governments and businesses. However, this approach can overlook the need for democratic governance and reduce development to individual acts of charity, which often do not address the root causes of poverty in rural communities. While skepticism about volunteering is often misplaced, the act of volunteer tourism can sometimes be seen as simple charity. However, when it is promoted as sustainable development and when gap-year companies market their services as part of development efforts, it can dilute the true meaning of development. The politics surrounding volunteer tourism can reflect a retreat from understanding global inequalities and the poverty faced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports that many of us listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help us get out of bed. This is why clock radios are popular. But how do you choose a good one? A panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

One model has a 'dual alarm function' that I initially thought would let you wake up to a buzzer, snooze for a bit, and then get up. However, the instruction booklet suggests using this feature to set two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and another for weekends. But who really schedules their life like that? This model is priced similarly to another one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a nice bonus. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to a peaceful morning. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size is an issue—it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that any clock radio he buys must leave enough space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was voted the best in terms of design and overall performance. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it,' even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I was impressed by the digital display, which has stylish grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze button allows you to tap it without opening your eyes. Unfortunately, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which led to confusion when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don’t have to reset it if someone accidentally unplugs it. Everyone liked this feature, but we found it complicated to set up. However, once we figured it out, we felt quite sophisticated.

Tom Granger criticized another model with a built-in lamp, calling it 'unbelievably tacky.' He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was difficult to position and not useful for reading, as it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed that tuning the radio was challenging. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, making me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, it has bright colors and a fun design, which appealed to both Tom Granger and me. Tom said he would choose this one because it stands out more than the others. In fact, its traditional controls were the only ones we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual states that 'the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time.' Paul Bridges laughed at this, saying the model was 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model we tested impressed Tom Granger because it was 'very standard and took up little space,' plus it has old-fashioned dial tuning. He said it was easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you can never be sure if you pressed the buttons correctly, which makes you doubt if it will work. He acknowledged that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I found the tuning a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. They are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward for protection. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, making them more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using their ball-rolling ability only as a last option.

Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in burrows. While all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do; some will remain awake throughout the year if conditions are suitable.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their dreams.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
