"Flying through the air and landing smoothly is an incredible feeling, but it can also be frightening. Sometimes, I don’t feel well, or the weather is bad, making it hard to see, but I push through. It’s tough to have a life outside of skiing since we train for ten months each year. I’ve given up a lot of my social life and friendships, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete on the same courses and receive equal treatment—it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and surprisingly won because I cycled faster than everyone else, even though I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day, including stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment required."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because very few schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to a lack of stability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy rowing and staying fit, and I appreciate the social aspect of the sport."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it was! I found Britain too confining and safe. I was very determined and disliked being controlled by others. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the most painful experience, covering 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. However, I set a record because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, making them hesitant to sponsor us."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, especially on highways. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman in racing has its challenges. When I approach a corner, men feel they must beat me, which has led to many tough moments. You need to be competitive and aggressive. Earning money in this sport is difficult, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s encouraging to see more women entering the sport each year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing comes from striving for perfection."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There’s a lot of pressure before races, and I really push myself during competitions. I often wonder why I do this, and I realize it’s because a) I feel happier when I’m fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also lower for women. However, we have established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could easily recognize the famous artist while he was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old, unreliable van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of my time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work in the hills. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have approached him to ask for his signature. I was nervous as I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below it. Even when Picasso's art was abstract, it often connected to real things, so his lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was even worse, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I managed to tell Picasso about my strong interest in art and my admiration for his work. After a while, I returned to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. However, he noticed that the lunch was still going on and asked, "Is that all? Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this opportunity? You might even draw his portrait."

With my sketchbook in hand, I went back to Picasso's table. I thought it was best not to ask if I could draw him, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, set my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled mischievously and made it hard for me to work. He acted out funny and strange expressions, rolling his eyes and sticking out his tongue, like a playful clown. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit challenged me to keep going. Despite his antics, I sensed he was testing my determination.

Eventually, Picasso settled down and allowed me to study him without distractions. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed more like a fit 60-year-old than someone about to turn 84. His dark eyes were youthful and intense, and I tried to capture that in my drawing. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed distant and absorbed in his own thoughts. 

When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my portrait, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. However, he insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he created a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single, lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Still, I look back on that day with gratitude. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This article explains the strategies that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. The Freshness Factor**  
Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. To create this impression, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors used in the store, like green, are chosen to suggest freshness. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, does not match this fresh image.

**B. Smart Product Placement**  
The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales. Supermarkets use technology to find out which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these spots, while less profitable but fast-selling items are also featured. Products at eye level are particularly sought after by manufacturers. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters, and items that go well together, like desserts next to ice cream, are often placed near each other.

**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This means shoppers must walk past more tempting, higher-priced items. Chain stores may also position their popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and encounter other tempting products along the way.

**D. Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from a crowded display style to a more boutique-like approach, showcasing limited fashion items. This gives the impression of exclusivity, even though their clothing is mass-produced. Their success comes from both good store design and appealing clothing.

**E. The Total Cost**  
Food shoppers often focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items to attract customers. They may even sell some staples at a loss to draw shoppers in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They achieve low prices by buying in bulk or negotiating discounts with manufacturers.

**F. The Price Tag**  
Shoppers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and pay more attention to individual prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can influence buying decisions. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Effective Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural light, helping customers see the true colors of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to highlight fresh produce.

**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. This design encourages customers to follow specific paths, known as the "Yellow Brick Road." However, some shoppers may hesitate to explore areas off these paths. For example, Marks and Spencer use wood or marble flooring for main routes, leading shoppers to more inviting carpeted sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotions**  
As you enter a supermarket, you might see large, colorful images of delicious food, which can be tempting if you're hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display advertisements as you shop. These trolleys use sensors to show relevant ads, like ready-made meals when you pass certain sections. They are designed to attract impulse buyers and reportedly increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, aged 58, is famous for reaching the summit of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written several books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sailing trip, where I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first experience on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

When we reached a steep drop, I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. After I finished, he politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit worried, but he managed to lower himself safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion to combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure.

I admired Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always consulted the crew first. Although most people hesitated to give him advice, it felt good to be part of the decision-making. Honestly, I found sailing quite challenging and boring. The moments of crisis were easier to handle because they got my adrenaline pumping. However, spending day after day in the middle of the sea was tough for me. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin was a natural sailor who enjoyed fixing the engine and the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was cramped, with six people on a 32-foot yacht designed for four. On a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other, but on the boat, we were always close together. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times while climbing when if Robin fell, he could have taken me down with him. I had to be very careful. I also underestimated how difficult Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we nearly fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted my decision. I knew he was worried about the boat and whether it would make it through the ice, but he still wanted to try climbing the mountain again.

The only time we had a serious issue was on the yacht on our way home. We were taking turns keeping watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me insecure, and I expressed my feelings. Robin quickly reassured me that I was misunderstanding the situation. While we enjoyed our trip to Skye, we truly got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, existing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since prehistoric times. In neolithic Britain, they discarded apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. Ancient people in Switzerland and the Caucasus mountains even stored dried apple halves for winter. These early apples were wild crab apples, small and different from the apples we know today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. One dessert apple, called Decio, was likely introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and Norman varieties quickly became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
During the thirteenth century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term 'costermonger,' meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This trend continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them valuable possessions. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed.' Born in 1774, he planted nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious beliefs led to many folktales about him.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa discovered a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named the apple 'Hawkey.' After sending it to a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples globally.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. She was known as 'Granny Smith' because she managed the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing among discarded fruit, transplanted it, and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she remarked, "Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from northern India to Africa. However, most apples come from just a few commercial varieties, often chosen for their appearance or ability to travel rather than their taste. This trend of uniformity is dulling our taste and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are beginning to demand more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity; we must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner and one of Britain's best 10,000-metre athletes, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain path leads from a quiet road in Nairobi to the start of the climb up Mount Kenya, the country’s highest peak. This beautiful but isolated place is called Nanyuk, and for the past three years, it has been my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners until my fourth winter training trip to Kenya. This time, I decided to break my routine. I participated in my first race in Kenya's thin air and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I received an invitation from the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss.

Training at high altitude increases the number of red blood cells, which helps carry more oxygen. This advantage has contributed to the success of many Kenyan runners. My first race in Africa, which took place before my time at the training camp, was also significant as it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. It was a humbling experience; out of 41 runners who finished ahead of me, only three were not Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I realized that Kenyan success is not only due to altitude. Kenyan runners are known for their straightforward approach to the sport. Their running style appears effortless, their diet is simple, and they seem to enjoy competing.

One of the less discussed factors in Kenyan success is their training methods. My time at the training camp revealed the answers. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and lush vegetation. The facilities are basic, with athletes living among regular students in shared dormitories. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The day starts at six in the morning, when we gather for a briefing from the coaches. "Run easy; you have a tough day ahead," the coach reminded us as we set off. Each day, we covered about 40 kilometers, just short of a marathon. Sundays were easier, with only one scheduled run of 20 kilometers.

Life at the camp was simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth were enough for morning preparations. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small, dimly lit dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After our runs, we would drive to one of the streams fed by Mount Kenya's melting glaciers for a proper bath. By the end of my stay, I had a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained solely by genetics, upbringing, or altitude. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the intense training, and the passion for success might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

As many people know, advertising is struggling. This decline started in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening globally. The sad reality is that advertising has not adapted to the fast changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as more brands and media options have emerged, audiences have become more divided. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.

Consider your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you might purchase only a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen, and for cars, you typically buy one every three years. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you include snacks, medicines, and other services, it is likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In contrast, there are about 32,500 branded products and services advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are analyzed by Media Register. The average consumer buys only 400 of these brands, which is about 4 percent. This challenges the common belief that half of advertising is wasted; in reality, it could be that 96 percent of advertising does not lead to purchases, but we cannot identify which part is wasted.

When you watch TV, try to count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. Most people find that only about one in 16 ads (6 percent) are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent of the ads may be wasted. Many people believe they are not influenced by advertising, but this is not true. Most people do not buy the majority of the brands they see advertised. 

Waste is a natural part of advertising through media. The idea that every reader or viewer will rush to buy all advertised brands is unrealistic. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many ads have shown that it can work. Advertisers need to reach a large audience to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as they cannot predict who will be interested.

Even the best-targeted advertising cannot guarantee a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between media advertising and personal selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every potential customer they meet. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all; they could contact those individuals directly.

For any advertiser, gaining one million new customers (about 2 percent of the adult population) is a significant achievement. The top-selling brands in supermarkets would be thrilled with an extra million customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can attract more than 2 percent of the population would be considered very successful, even though this is still a small portion of the total audience. While mass media can be a cost-effective way to reach people, advertising must become more focused to be effective again.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Explores Britain's Most Eco-Friendly Home**

Charles Clover visits Southwell in Nottinghamshire, home to Britain's least-known ancient cathedral, Southwell Minster. This cathedral is admired by environmentally conscious writers for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen in the thirteenth century. Nearby is the 'autonomous house,' designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale, which is known as Britain's greenest home.

The Vales have created a home that uses rainwater for drinking and washing, recycles sewage into compost, and heats the house using waste heat from appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house, which looks traditional with its clay tile roof, is located 300 yards from the Minster and blends in with the town's nineteenth-century architecture. It was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you hear complete silence. The house is extremely well-insulated, with triple-glazed windows filled with krypton gas, making it very quiet inside. Once inside, after removing your shoes as requested by Robert, you experience a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow, as the house is designed to be draught-proof, even having a small air-locked door for the cats.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been committed to environmental issues since the 1970s when they wrote a book called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to eliminate the need for mains water. They installed composting toilets, rainwater tanks in the cellar, and copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. They also let washing water flow into the garden, as they do not use a dishwasher, believing it is wrong to use harsh detergents.

Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much less harmful to the environment without living in darkness." The only medieval feature of the house is its design, with a hall that includes the fireplace and staircase, extending to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p—much less than what other four-bedroom homes use for heating.

Soon, they will install £20,000 worth of solar panels and equipment in the garden, which will allow the house to generate more electricity than it uses. They will still draw electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances but will have enough surplus to eventually charge an electric car. The only source of heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they rarely use except during the coldest days.

When asked if the house is warm in winter, Robert shared that during a visit in February, it was too warm to light the fire, with the first-floor temperature at 18°C. He believes this is comfortable because there are no draughts and everything feels the same temperature. He notes that people in the past were comfortable at lower temperatures due to their clothing. He suggests that those living in older homes should adapt to the past ways of living, though this idea may not be popular.

The house's success lies in its low-tech design, which minimizes potential problems. Most materials were sourced from local builders and installed by local craftsmen, making it affordable to build—costing the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are resistant to this approach.

**The Camera Never Lies**

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, considered himself a rational person and even a scientist. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article where he accepted fairies as supernatural beings. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out images of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a key idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In reality, it can, and it always has. Nowadays, we often use computer software to edit our digital images, and it is a misconception that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were respected like doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture were crafted by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased. Heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used the beautiful wrought iron that blacksmiths created. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more creative approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced seems repetitive, with manufacturers labeling their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks that look similar to each other.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be entering a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are becoming more aware of the craft. 

Modern power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld with less effort. Dawson explains that these artists now have the tools to express their creativity. The exhibition features about 250 pieces, including bookends and a spiral staircase, with prices starting at £90 and going up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual artists, but a portion will be kept by the Association to promote quality ironwork.

Dawson has contributed an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a hand-blown glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and flow into shape when it’s hot, comparing it to drawing with metal in space. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals that are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, finds it magical because it is soft when hot but becomes hard and unyielding when it cools.

Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, while another resembles a Celtic cross. She appreciates the cold, hard nature of steel and how it feels permanent. No other metal has provided as much visual enjoyment or a sense of security. It seems likely that iron will continue to be used for decorative purposes for many years to come, as long as we can avoid more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**

I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying, even for me. 

The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn’t planned to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. Plus, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lifestyles.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" to write an article about others trying to quit. I clearly stated, "I won’t be trying to stop myself; I’m here to write, not to quit." I thought I was being reasonable because I genuinely enjoyed smoking. It brought me real pleasure.

The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about quitting started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of stopping began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker started to give me a sense of power. It was a personal feeling that didn’t involve anyone else. Could I also achieve other things?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, disappeared after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had worried that I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was just relaxing at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I’ve come to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to adjust to—like eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre intermission. These are all moments when I would have previously smoked.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been testing my friends on their knowledge of her. When I tell them I am writing her biography, I watch their reactions. If they seem surprised and ask if there is already a biography, they pass the test. 

Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? The fact that she is the only British woman to win a Nobel Prize should be enough. Anyone else with such an achievement in literature would be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend and worked in the same field. I went to a local bookshop, but I found no biographies of Pauling. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a highly influential chemist and a Nobel Prize winner in both chemistry and peace.

Even scientists sometimes think that biographies about scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. This idea that scientists are less interesting than artists or writers is a common misconception. 

Some scientists are very careful about their public image. A well-known geneticist told me he would be happy to discuss his work but did not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This reluctance to share personal stories can create a false image of science and may discourage young people from pursuing scientific careers.

Fortunately, this is changing. Nowadays, scientists often appear in public in ways that go beyond traditional interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. While some may find this surprising, these activities help make scientists more relatable to the public.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be dry and overly respectful, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been portrayed with their flaws on display. Readers find it interesting to see how these brilliant minds dealt with personal challenges, even if those challenges seem unrelated to their scientific work.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her research. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She achieved these successes by pushing scientific techniques to new levels. However, she also balanced her career with her family life, raising three children and being married to a husband who was often away for work.

Her personal life may not be directly related to her scientific achievements, but it shows how she managed to integrate different aspects of her life. There is much in her story that is universally interesting, but it is also important to recognize her scientific contributions. 

Communicating the passion for science is a challenge for biographers. Many readers may not have the background to understand complex scientific ideas without extensive explanation. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that educated people who would feel embarrassed not to recognize a famous literary figure often remain unaware of the significant contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for her unique ability to find water. She uses a forked hazel stick to detect underground water sources. Farmers whose wells have dried up often seek her help. Along with her husband, she runs a well-drilling business that uses modern equipment like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, when it comes to finding water, she relies solely on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This skill, known as dowsing, involves locating water, minerals, and lost items underground. There are various theories about how dowsing works, ranging from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One popular theory suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, with water vibrating more than other materials. Some dowsers claim they can sense or even smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to droughts, Margaret has been very busy, sometimes having a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells, as wells can last a long time, meaning she usually sees each customer only once. Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns, where installing water pipes is too expensive, and developers of golf courses who need water for their facilities.

Margaret typically looks for water at depths of 50 to 70 meters. She emphasizes the importance of drilling in safe locations to avoid contamination from waste. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and as long as it is brought up directly, it should be clean. However, she notes that Cornwall has many minerals, so they must be cautious about iron in the water. 

Electricity is also necessary to operate the pump, but running power lines over long distances can be costly, so it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. Once these factors are considered, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still over the map, and it swings when she is above a water source.

After identifying potential areas on the map, she walks the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation and sways slightly. Once this feeling passes, she uses the stick to find the exact drilling spot. By holding the two forks of the stick and applying slight tension, she can tell if water is directly below. If the stick rises, it indicates water is present. 

It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates; even a small mistake can mean missing the water entirely. Margaret and her husband often dowse the same area, and they usually agree on where to drill. If they disagree, they will continue searching until they reach a consensus.

Margaret's skills are not just a local tradition; they have intrigued anthropologists and writers for a long time. She describes her ability as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. Without this unique skill, it would be difficult for her family to sustain their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be exciting to try something completely different. We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, 23, is a young mother with two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, 30, who works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant. 

Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and full of people, which was very different from her hometown. She felt nervous and overwhelmed. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when she tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and reassured her that everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, when the restaurant opened, there was already a long line of customers, and Amanda felt anxious about remembering their orders. Luckily, the ordering system was automated, which made things easier. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she struggled to hear customers over the loud music. She often had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to relax her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, which surprised Amanda. She realized that waitressing is much more demanding than she thought. She used to think it was an easy job, but it actually requires a friendly personality and the ability to handle a busy environment. Amanda, who is quite shy, felt she could never manage a Saturday night shift when it gets really hectic. She was also disappointed with the tips she received, especially from wealthy customers. After the experience, she was relieved to return to her children, as being a mother felt much easier in comparison!

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy, who is 30, was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She had heard that Amanda's daughters could be mischievous, but she thought she could handle it. 

After Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have three hours of peace. However, she soon found a note from Amanda reminding her of all the chores she still had to do, like making the beds and doing laundry. 

At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, quickly shopped for groceries, and took her home for lunch. But when she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and played a loud game. Cindy tried to stay calm, thinking they would tire out soon, but she was wrong. She thought she had good energy, but the girls outlasted her! After much effort, she finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the real challenge began. The girls kept asking for glasses of water, which was just a trick to get them downstairs to watch TV. Cindy realized how tiring it is to take care of two small children. There was no time for herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. Despite the challenges, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, 30, a primary school teacher. 

On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt luxurious! She was unsure how to dress for school, wanting to look appropriate instead of in her usual farm clothes. At assembly, she faced about 400 students and hoped she wouldn’t stand out too much. 

In class, the children worked in small groups on math, which was different from her own school experience. She also helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There was so much to do before classes resumed. She attended a staff meeting and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson, which she enjoyed, followed by a French lesson where the children practiced speaking with her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, she was exhausted, while the children seemed full of energy. Speaking in front of the class was the hardest part for her. Although teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had already been working for three hours! Rosemary's farm is large, with many animals and produces milk, ice cream, and yogurt.

Hilary spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling containers with milk and making ice cream. She had to resist the temptation to taste everything! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a fallen ewe. If sheep are not checked regularly, they can die, which is especially difficult in winter. After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! 

Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children, as animals don’t talk back. The hardest part of farming is the constant work; cows need to be milked twice daily, making it hard to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of vacation each year. While farming may seem romantic, the reality is quite different. The income can be unstable, and she wouldn’t want to rely on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many successful musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces. When you meet him, he looks youthful and has a bright personality, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a television feature was made about his work, filmed in both London and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo and began his career because of a Christmas gift he received when he was eight. His father, who did not play music but enjoyed Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother arranged for him to take lessons from the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, someone who was passionate about the trumpet and always looking for ways to improve.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to create a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and build a relationship with them. From the start, he had a unique sound that was recognizable, which he considers the first thing he developed.

Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his ambition to become a professional trumpet player and allowed him to practice as much as he wanted. At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud discouraged him from joining an orchestra, saying that "Playing in the orchestra is like digging in the garden."

Hardenberger was aware that he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with the audience. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only the first round pieces but advanced to the second round. Fortunately, he was familiar with most of the pieces in that round as well. However, in the final, he faced a concerto that intimidated him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even though he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.

Hardenberger's honest view of his work might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what makes his communication with the audience special, believing that trying to explain it could ruin it. He feels that the true power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a composed, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

C. This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears from the story but returns after World War II, having learned to value the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway approaches her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's outlook on life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her entertaining manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the underlying sadness in everyday life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who share their experiences in different professions, discussing the positives, negatives, and their typical workdays.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7:00 am, and arrive at work by 8:00 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries last about three hours, but some can take all day. Occasionally, I work for ten hours straight without eating or taking breaks. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about the next day’s tasks. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is incredibly rewarding, making up for the times it doesn’t. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time constraints can make this challenging. I usually leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. I am on call some nights and weekends, and I always carry my pager. During holidays, I often worry about my patients and dream about operating at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team of three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only 10-15% being actual design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, especially with tight deadlines. Lunch is at 1:00 pm for an hour, and we often go to a pub. If the client is happy with my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be much later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7:00 am, but on some days, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5:00 am for long-haul flights. Around 10:30 or 11:00 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sedentary job, I pay attention to my diet and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. I often get asked for recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, allowing me to plan my routes. While most passengers are polite, some can be rude. I have built good relationships with my regular clients. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7:00 am, leave home by 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11:00 am, we take a break for a big breakfast at a local café. In summer, I may work until 10:00 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden design, I usually meet them in the evening. We focus on using old materials to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren’t great, but it’s very satisfying to see a completed project bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. However, I sleep well because my job is physically demanding."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that contractors follow the schedule and safety guidelines while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate site professionals and solve problems. The contractors start at 6:00 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. My day involves reviewing paperwork and answering design questions. I usually take a half-hour lunch between 2:00 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we monitor the contractors' work, it can lead to conflicts, so we need to maintain open communication. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but I act immediately if something urgent arises. I typically leave the site around 6:00 pm and am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am to reach the office by 7:30 am. My job involves managing customer development programs for our credit card users. I launch and oversee the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I maintain contact with current card users, attract new ones, and build partnerships with companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle advertising for the membership program across Europe, meeting with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to address any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by reviewing the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. I listen to demo tapes carefully, knowing that they represent people's hard work, and I try to provide constructive feedback. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, selecting songs, a producer, and additional musicians. I also share my vision for the album with the marketing team. I manage budgets and expenses. I leave work by 7:00 pm at the earliest, and most evenings I attend concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule to see if we have any client meetings that day. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and helping them find furniture. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, sourcing them from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with our restorer and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while having coffee to stay updated on the industry, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle the accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I leave work at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to relax after work.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am and start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over from the night shift. I rotate between four control positions in the tower, working for about an hour and a half at each station before taking a break. My team, which includes other controllers and a supervisor, manages aircraft movements. In winter, we handle around 1,000 movements daily, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic regulations. This job is quite stressful, and I take sick leave if I feel unwell. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. My first task is to start the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate staff breaks. I spend the morning assisting customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss upcoming titles with them. I need to estimate how many copies we might sell of each title. When we want to feature a new book, I ensure it arrives on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work a late shift, closing the computer system and locking up before going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. My job is to assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, warning clients about potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly to gather information. I type the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, but it can be hard to relax, and I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others, drives change, and guides people towards a common goal. Leadership is not about physical traits like height, nor is it just about being smart. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is crucial, and a good leader should express it clearly and confidently. Dixon emphasizes the importance of saying "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Recognizing Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, who directs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

**C. Comparing Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? A good leader motivates and supports you, while a bad leader makes you feel unimportant and blames you when things go wrong. The first one leads effectively; the second one just manages poorly.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers prefer to work within set limits, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, states that a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can enhance your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to consider:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and act on them when you feel inspired.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is valuable, but sometimes strong leadership is necessary. Try different leadership styles. If you usually negotiate, take the lead instead, and see how it changes the outcome.  
- Set goals and strive to exceed them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career opportunities.

**F. Developing Leadership Skills**  
- Leadership doesn’t just happen; it develops through taking charge, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and provide feedback.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will be immediately accepted. It might even push people away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your input is crucial and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Film Critic Nick James Reviews Recent Releases**

**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created this tense Cold War thriller about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The interactions and modest bravery of foreman Bud and his team remind us of similar heroes in Howard Hawks' films. The production design and special effects are outstanding, but the dialogue and character development feel weak. Despite the skill in filmmaking, the story is more like a B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the Guadalcanal battle, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different perspective compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often staying true to the book. He focuses on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife, which is portrayed more harshly than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
This film, loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, is a fun swashbuckler that stands out among musketeer stories. Fabrice Luchini plays a cunning politician who secretly causes chaos. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is brief. Daniel Auteuil, while perhaps too serious for a light-hearted film, also shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama clichés with such charm and energy that it doesn’t feel like a problem.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 20th-century Rotterdam, this film tells a somber story. The detailed production and costume design make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless in evicting tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the plot, but the filmmakers focus too much on historical details, neglecting the dark and powerful story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skill, especially in sound editing, where every sound is clear. The storytelling is harsh, and whenever there’s a quiet moment, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act unscrupulously in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
Promoted as featuring "forty-eight international stars," this three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck has four directors and 23,000 extras, making it feel overdone. The early scenes, where battle-hardened veterans wait for news about the invasion, drag on for both the audience and the soldiers. Logistically impressive, it loses impact on video, making it a less engaging experience.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is indeed very engaging. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He unexpectedly has to defend his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the outcome uncertain until the very end, and there is a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a strong debut in a competitive genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a bang and follows the charming Sigismondo, a troubleshooter for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church intrigue, and serious murder, but we are confident he will uncover the guilty parties. The plot is complex, and the book is a bit longer than necessary, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a fresh new detective from first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector who finds herself in a unique position to investigate when a strange man collapses at her feet. Despite facing criticism from various people, including a handsome local detective sergeant, brave and adaptable Leah proves to be a strong character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features the intelligent private investigator Spenser, who helps his friend Hawk remove drug dealers from a troubled neighborhood in Boston. The dialogue is quick and sharp, and while there are fewer deaths than usual, the story includes more philosophical elements. As always, Parker delivers high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features her regular detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, as they investigate an attack and burglary at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's straightforward writing style and keen observation of unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by the husband-and-wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, and the defender becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book skillfully combines elements of romance, money, and violence to create a gripping suspense novel.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw presents actor Philip Fletcher as the intended victim. A humorous cast of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels that this is not the right direction for his career. While Simon Shaw usually entertains, this shift from dark comedy to farce does not quite meet his usual high standards.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best work in a while. It follows Canadian police as they search for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow and expertly crafted build-up of tension, along with the portrayal of the intelligent but troubled robber, elevates this novel above the typical detective story.

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age have decided to take this leap. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 and feeling nervous. I have traveled before; after university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America, and I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then life happened—I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Gradually, I realized I was sacrificing my own happiness for my paycheck. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 

I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship and don’t have strong career goals, so I feel I should make the most of this freedom—if only for my friends! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and am already behind schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the football season to start?” 

Letting go of emotional ties makes it harder. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can handle backpacking again. Will I adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their established lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says there’s a growing realization that adventure is available: “People who always say, ‘I wish I had that opportunity’ are realizing they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.”

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance for one last adventure before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip. There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career when I return, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!” 

For Matt, who just left the Army, his year of travel was transformative. “In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to change that mindset to live well as a civilian.” While everyone has different reasons for traveling at this age, there are common themes. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today’s workforce is more flexible. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Some larger companies even have career-break policies, knowing that if they invest in training someone, it’s good to have them return rather than go to a competitor.

Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of everyday travelers, notes that more thirty-somethings are reassessing their lives. “If you’re not happy with your job—and many aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People now know that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t permanent. Travel allows you to step back and think about your life.” 

Is this desire to travel just a sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox disagrees. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about just paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, believes he’s not running away. “I’m running towards something. I want to grab opportunities for myself.” But he also feels some anxiety about leaving behind his comfortable routine—going to the office every day, greeting everyone, and enjoying a cup of coffee.

I share Ben’s concerns about leaving a stable life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be making this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out, “This is common. There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or job loss, that pushes people to travel.” It may have taken a nudge to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll take pride in having embraced life. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt disconnected from the technological changes. In this piece, she shares how she turned her home into an effective workplace.

Last Christmas, I turned 37 and realized I needed to revive my journalism career, which I thought was lost due to technology.
