Looking at my resume, I saw I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the latest technology. I felt that no one would trust me with a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads required experience in desktop publishing, which I lacked. I thought I had a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to design a page on a computer. I was known as the family technophobe; even calculators confused me, and I still couldn’t figure out how to use the timer on the video.

I knew I had to act quickly to fill the gap in my career. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a local newspaper competition and, surprisingly, my family won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with strangers from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I created a mini-office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem connecting me to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

The children were already comfortable with computers from school, but I was nervous, fearing I would lose my work by pressing the wrong button. I was wrong. Although I wasn’t very skilled, I learned the basics, and it turned out to be logical and straightforward. With persistence, I improved a little each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk has always been a chaotic mess, and I often lost important papers. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help me track income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. For a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask for information in journalism forums, and discuss the pros and cons of working from home with people worldwide.

However, there are downsides to working from home. You can feel isolated without physical contact with others. There are also distractions, like household chores, and when the kids are home, we often argue over who gets to use the computer. Yet, more people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education and entertainment, but also for the convenience of avoiding the daily commute to the city.

As we move into the next century, what defines home workers? A report called PC Usage in UK Homes describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, 32% have a CD-ROM, 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities are endless in this digital age.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out against the historic backdrop of Edinburgh. But are the exhibits inside just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.

You can't miss the new Museum of Scotland, located at the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh. It features a large yellow sandstone tower and unique, wedge-shaped buildings topped with a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reactions, with some calling it a "masterpiece" and others expressing skepticism. Now, as the inside prepares for its opening, the exhibitions are expected to face similar opinions.

Forget debates about whether the museum tells a national story or follows a chronological order. The answer is yes; it presents a rich tapestry of stories, each linked to important historical objects. There is a timeline to help visitors navigate, but it does not restrict the displays. The museum does not let its national treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and Holyrood chapel silver, be overshadowed by national pride.

The main concern, assuming the collections are well-preserved, is whether visitors will find the museum engaging enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes that a visit should be enjoyable and visually appealing, aimed at those with little prior knowledge. Despite this openness, Clarke insists on a strict approach to what is displayed. He rejects recreations and imaginative scenes, stating that they misrepresent the past. He believes the public deserves the truth.

At this museum, what you see reflects what experts know. The challenge for visitors is whether the stories of the objects can be communicated effectively through explanation panels, captions, and multimedia, with only about 30 computers available throughout the museum. With less than three days before the opening, it remains uncertain.

Some aspects are clear, though. The stunning views of Edinburgh Castle are breathtaking. Inside, visitors notice a series of interconnected galleries of various sizes and shapes, with pale walls designed to resemble large stone blocks and deep display cases. Natural light pours in through narrow windows and roof lights, creating a space for visitors to reflect on each item.

Thanks to a 12-member Junior board made up of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland, the museum includes a Discovery Centre. The group wanted a way to interact with the displays. Although they didn't get that, they succeeded in creating a dedicated hands-on area for children in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition gallery. As a result, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition, set to change every three years. It features a mix of objects chosen by Scottish people and notable figures that have significantly impacted life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, thermos flasks, and favorite toys. While this idea is entertaining, it feels somewhat superficial and does not fully address serious topics. However, it may gain depth when the computerized collection of personal stories and memories goes live next week.

Overall, Dr. Clarke is correct in saying that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it works well from the inside and the top, but whether it fits its location is still up for debate.

**The Future of Print Media**

The idea of "transition" is often seen as a positive change. It suggests moving smoothly from one state to another. However, the transition of newspapers to the online world is uncertain and uncomfortable. Many believe that this change is inevitable, as print newspaper sales are declining while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, major newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, while their online traffic continues to grow.

However, the situation is more complex than it seems. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers showed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies daily. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has compensated for this decline. Interestingly, news and current affairs magazines have also seen a 5.4% increase in sales.

The same trend can be observed in the book industry. E-readers like Kindle are becoming very popular, with significant sales growth this year. Yet, when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books over the past six months, they found only a slight decrease of 0.4%. This suggests that both digital and print formats can coexist.

The belief that young people are completely abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries in Europe show varying trends. For instance, the UK has seen a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, while Germany's decline is only 7%, and France has experienced a mere 3.1% fall.

These differences indicate that the situation is more complicated than the idea of a digital revolution suggests. In the past, analysts believed that rising online advertising revenues would support the shift to digital newspapers. However, digital ad revenues are now declining, leading many US newspapers to implement paywalls for their content. 

To attract paying readers, some newspapers are offering packages that include both print and digital access. This shows that print remains an important tool for selling online subscriptions, as print advertising generates significantly more revenue than online ads. 

Maintaining both a print edition and a website is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print media still holds a strong presence, and being noticed online is increasingly difficult.

**Photographing People**

People are the most fascinating subjects for photography. A photo that includes a person is usually more interesting than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of a camera can sometimes make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Have people stand at different angles and distances, and if possible, at different heights. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so that all faces are visible, or raise your camera to get a better view.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Don’t pretend you’re not taking a picture when it’s obvious you are; this can create tension. Most people will agree to have their photo taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be less interesting if the subject looks away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo is more powerful if the subject looks directly at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, and remind them just before you take the shot. You can also say something funny to capture a genuine reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of direct eye contact, you can have the subject focus on something in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it gives the viewer a sense of observing a moment. Candid shots can be very engaging, and the subject's expression is crucial.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they communicate feelings instantly.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of faces are impactful, the background can add context and interest. When including a background, avoid irrelevant details and focus on what matters. Ensure the subject stands out against the background, perhaps by using a wide-angle lens.

**H. Interaction**  
Capturing moments where people interact—like talking, laughing, or working together—can lead to great photos. Couples, parents with children, and teams are all good subjects. Look for eye contact or physical connections, like a hand on an arm, to show relationships.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or landscape. Position your subjects close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. An elevated camera position can help achieve this balance.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide the purpose of your photo. If you want a clear memory of someone you met briefly, ask them to pose against a nice background. However, family photos can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and can capture genuine moments, making them more memorable in the future.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means her paintings create an illusion of reality that tricks the eye. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her unique perspective on art.

Unlike many artists, Sarah does not sign her work unless asked. She believes that the artwork itself is what matters, not the artist. She is very modest and almost wants people to think her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes her uncomfortable during interviews. When asked about being photographed, she covers her face in embarrassment. However, after some time, she relaxes, and the conversation becomes enjoyable and funny.

Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She trained for two years in drawing at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, she found illustration unfulfilling and began working with a well-known decorator, Jim Smart. He encouraged her to try trompe-l'oeil, and she quickly became passionate about it. She decided to start her own business, unsure of where it would lead but feeling it was the right choice.

Her skills in observation and attention to detail, developed through her illustration work, are crucial for her trompe-l'oeil art. She believes that trompe-l'oeil cannot be taught; it is learned through life experiences and careful observation. Sarah insists she is still learning and believes that if you think you have mastered something, you should stop.

She is honest about her weaknesses, such as her inability to paint bread realistically. When faced with a large project, like painting a ceiling at Lulworth Castle, she struggled with measurements and questioned her abilities. This self-doubt leads her to speak about her work in a detached way, as if it is done by someone else.

Despite her modesty, Sarah's trompe-l'oeil art is exceptional and stands out from others in the field. She has completed many significant projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that tricks the viewer into thinking they can enter two more rooms.

However, trompe-l'oeil art has a challenge: once the viewer understands the trick, they may lose interest. Sarah knows this and believes that her art must first draw people in and then engage their imagination. She also thinks that trompe-l'oeil should be personal to the client. She enjoys working closely with her clients, as their ideas often inspire her work. Some clients become friends because she spends so much time with them during projects.

Sarah appreciates her clients, especially those who allow her creative freedom. They seem happy with her work, which keeps her busy, even though she downplays her talent. She prefers not to boast about herself, saying she is reserved and does not want her work to be loud. While this may be true, her art and personality are anything but boring. Her work deserves more recognition, and I am willing to promote it, even if she might not like it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the important 'people skills' needed to succeed in our careers.

A. The workplace is changing. We are now evaluated not only on our intelligence and skills but also on how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is increasingly used to decide who gets hired or promoted. It helps identify who is likely to excel and who may not. Regardless of our current jobs, these criteria are essential for our future employability. They focus less on academic performance and more on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness—collectively known as emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is uncertain, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For years, these traits have been referred to by various names, such as 'character' and 'soft skills.' Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence.' This term generally means the ability to understand and manage our own emotions and those of others, using feelings to guide our thoughts and actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people mistakenly think it only means being nice, but it can also involve confronting someone with difficult truths when necessary. It is not about expressing feelings freely but managing them effectively to help teams work together towards common goals.

C. More companies recognize that fostering emotional intelligence is vital for effective management. The more complex a job is, the more important emotional intelligence becomes. A lack of these skills can limit a person's ability to use their technical knowledge effectively. While some individuals have succeeded despite lacking emotional intelligence, as work becomes more collaborative, companies that promote teamwork gain a competitive advantage. In today's work environment, where teamwork and customer focus are essential, emotional intelligence is crucial for success in every job worldwide.

D. Unlike IQ, which remains relatively stable, emotional intelligence can develop throughout our lives as we learn from experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and improving their empathy and social skills over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often referred to as maturity. Not only can we learn these skills, but we can also add them to our toolkit for navigating our careers, especially in a time when job stability is uncertain. While emotional intelligence is not a guaranteed solution for struggling organizations, ignoring the human aspect can hinder overall effectiveness.

Text: 'Should the media profit from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important news events, but social media has truly changed citizen photography. As news often breaks on social networks, some journalists now use these platforms for images during fast-moving events. However, some reporters have shared user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Although there is guidance stating that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, the question of whether this is ethical is still debated. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, highlighting the significant role of UGC in the future of media. To maintain a good relationship with the public, the media must ensure that individuals are fairly compensated for their work and that permission is always obtained.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old and comes from traditional Chinese medicine. This system also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, physical manipulation, and exercise. While acupuncture can treat various health issues, it is particularly noted for its effectiveness in pain relief. Many general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists in the West use it for this purpose.

**Understanding Traditional Chinese Medicine**

Traditional Chinese medicine views health as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, known as Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to a specific organ, and many smaller ones that deliver Qi to every cell. When the flow of Qi is disrupted, it can lead to weakness or illness. During a consultation, an acupuncturist will assess your Qi by checking your pulse, examining your tongue, and looking at your overall health. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and lifestyle habits like eating and sleeping.

**Acupuncture Points**

The acupuncture points are linked to the meridians and may not be located near the area of pain. Patients often report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is gently moved. This can be done manually or with an electro-acupuncture machine. Acupuncturists believe that this sensation indicates the needle has connected with the Qi in the meridian. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more that are used less frequently.

**Scientific Understanding of Acupuncture**

While Western doctors may not accept all aspects of traditional Chinese medicine, many acknowledge that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientific studies suggest that acupuncture may work by blocking pain signals from reaching the brain or by releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals called endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Acupuncture is often sought by people with chronic pain when other treatments have failed. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-surgery pain. Acupuncturists also claim it can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Applications of Acupuncture**

Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over two millennia, its use as an alternative to anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped some Western doctors recognize its potential. In China today, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, including tonsillectomies and heart surgeries. It can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or alongside medications. While some patients report significant pain relief, experiences can vary. Acupuncturists argue that acupuncture has fewer side effects than traditional anesthesia, such as nausea, and allows for quicker recovery.

**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**

Clinical trials on acupuncture can be challenging, but studies show that 50 to 80 percent of patients find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally agree with this success rate, although they acknowledge that it may not work for everyone. They suggest that patients with long-term pain may need six to seven sessions to feel significant relief, but some improvement can often be noticed after just two or three visits.

**A Holistic Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, meaning they consider the whole person rather than just specific symptoms. They spend time diagnosing the issue and looking for underlying problems in the Qi. They also consider external factors that may affect the pain, such as weather conditions or the nature of the pain itself. This comprehensive approach is not typically used by most medical doctors.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using their methods can lead to deeper healing, which is hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor for further investigation if needed.

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a deep and creative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she carries an air of quiet confidence. One could easily imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school if she had not chosen to write detective stories filled with unexpected twists. However, it quickly becomes clear that her confident demeanor is a cover for her shyness. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, is based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh prefers to solve crimes alone, just like James prefers to write in solitude. She needs complete privacy to write, no matter where she is.

Despite her success, she is too humble to agree that she is the most famous crime writer in Britain, even though millions read her twelve major detective novels worldwide. She admires the work of her close friend Ruth Rendell, especially her psychological novels written under the name Barbara Vine. The books she enjoys most are often by female authors like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, but she also appreciates male writers like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she considers great novelists of their time.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published, and she is now in her seventies. Born in Oxford, she grew up mainly in Cambridge, where her family moved when she was 11. It was there that she met her husband, a university student, and she chose Cambridge as the setting for one of her novels, An Unsuitable Job For A Woman.

James has faced many challenges in her life. Her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very ill, and she had to work long hours to support him and their two young daughters, Clare and Jane. Although she had many ideas for stories, she struggled to find the time to write. Fortunately, her husband's parents helped care for the children, providing them with stability during tough times.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills effectively. At one point, she managed five psychiatric outpatient clinics. She then spent eleven years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and later in the Criminal Law section, focusing on juvenile crime. During her time in forensic science, she became accustomed to seeing dead bodies, but her interest was not in death itself. Instead, she was drawn to the structure and craft of writing a crime novel. 

James has always loved reading detective stories and knew she wanted to be a writer. She did not want to write about her own traumatic experiences, so she found writing detective stories to be a great way to learn the craft of serious novel writing while keeping her personal life separate. Over time, she realized that it was possible to follow the traditional format of a detective story while still creating a meaningful novel about human nature. For her, writing detective stories is a way to bring order to chaos, and solving a crime reinforces the value of life, even if that life is difficult. She believes that no one truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can significantly influence whether you are considered suitable for the position. Handwriting analysis, known as graphology, is recognized as a legitimate science in many places. Researchers suggest it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can also reveal psychological conditions and emotional problems. 

Graphology is increasingly used for career guidance and as a supplement to job interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to analyze the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the effectiveness of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes it deserves more attention. She argues that handwriting can reflect psychological traits and some medical conditions. According to her, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help assess mental abilities, whether someone should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a manipulative or honest character."

Ms. Marne claims that graphology can be especially useful in identifying potential criminal behavior. She notes that criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly formed and sometimes childish. Many criminals come from disadvantaged backgrounds and show signs of emotional development issues, which can be reflected in their handwriting. She states, "I can determine if people are honest, manipulative, or trustworthy." 

Young male offenders often have tall letters, suggesting they live in a fantasy world and dream of success. Graphologists can also predict if someone is likely to become violent, if they are under extreme stress, or if they have psychopathic traits. Handwriting can even indicate potential suicide risks. Ms. Marne explains that heart and lung issues can also be detected through handwriting. While one sample may not provide enough information, changes in handwriting over time, such as a previously stable signature becoming shaky, can signal serious problems. A significant emotional upset can also temporarily alter a person's signature.

Ms. Marne describes how handwriting can reveal various psychological traits. For example, people whose letters connect like threads may be clever but deceitful. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing suggests sensitivity and low energy. Originality in handwriting, or how much it differs from standard script, indicates confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing often signifies someone who prefers solitude. Very small signatures can show feelings of inferiority, while circles over the letter "i" indicate a desire for attention. Heavy crossing of the letter "t" can suggest intolerance and a condescending attitude.

Ms. Marne believes that it takes six years of study and practice to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She feels more research is needed to establish graphology as a scientific discipline, and she is optimistic that this will happen soon. She claims, "It's actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it reveals a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without needing to ask potentially misleading questions."

Despite these intriguing claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists criticize graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the writing style taught, and that it holds no deeper significance.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**

Fresh air and comfortable chairs are essential for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a recent survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their assessments.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very basic, with no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and windows that open directly to the street. Surprisingly, the small team of seven seems happy and has few complaints. They adapt to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, similar to how they would at home. This may be the reason for their happiness: they have created a comfortable, homely work environment without unnecessary rules.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and often creates poor posture. Many chairs are old, not adjustable, and some are broken. However, the staff has a varied work schedule that includes office work, client meetings, and presentations, which helps prevent fatigue and boredom.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The team enjoys the variety of tasks and the office's flexibility. They feel the office is "just the right size"—small enough to know what everyone is doing, yet large enough to focus on individual work. The office is attractive and promotes both efficiency and creativity.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office may not be exciting, but it is comfortable and staff do not dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, partly due to a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has hired an ergonomist, so the chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good. The layout could be better, but the environment feels impersonal with plain grey walls.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most employees have been there for over five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could improve by rearranging desks to facilitate information sharing and displaying project updates on the walls.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office receives mixed reviews. It feels like being in a glass case, with many people around. Despite having both smokers and non-smokers, the air quality is acceptable, and smoke is not noticeable even close to a smoker.

- **Ergonomist:** The office design is standard and uninspiring. The desks are barely adequate, and not all chairs meet ergonomic standards. Computer screens are often placed on low desks, which is not suitable for modern equipment.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Staff support each other well and have good technology. The office has many communication awards on display, but the wood paneling and brown carpet create a dull atmosphere. However, the office is busy and active.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many issues. The air conditioning is poorly controlled, leading to uncomfortable temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most employees have insufficient desk space. It is also very dusty, with dust collecting in many areas.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is more suitable for a workshop than an office. Many chairs are old and do not provide proper support for keyboard users, especially those shorter than 1.75 meters. 

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office has old, dirty chairs and carpets, and there is a lot of dust. There is much room for improvement, including better air conditioning and recognition of individual achievements. During our visit, there were few conversations, and everyone seemed stressed and overwhelmed by deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular, accessible to everyone, and Americans chew about 12 million sticks every day. This ancient practice has turned into a big business. Each stick of chewing gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered food and must meet the standards set by the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today’s gum is mostly made from synthetic materials, including pine resins and softeners that help maintain flavor and improve texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, marking the beginning of commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother, more enjoyable, and more elastic, leading to the growth of a new industry. However, efforts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not been successful. As the demand for chewing gum increased, synthetic alternatives were created.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, struggle to make a living. They trek for miles to collect sap from scattered sapodilla trees in very humid conditions. Their work environment is dangerous, with poisonous snakes and many insects, including a fly that lays eggs in their ears and noses. Despite these risks, experienced chicleros climb trees quickly to cut the bark and collect the sap in bags. They then carry the sap to a camp, where it is boiled until it becomes sticky and is formed into bricks. Life at the camp is tough, with a boring diet mainly of maize and local alcohol made from sugar cane. 

Even though this work is hard, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have shifted to synthetic ingredients to lower costs and meet demand.

Meanwhile, gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. They claim that chewing gum helps people relax, boosts energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were regularly given gum. One of the main benefits of gum is that it can help reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but our saliva can neutralize this acid and provide minerals like calcium and fluoride, which protect our teeth. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva production.

Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to make the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of land in America is dedicated to growing mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the peacefulness of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The hotel offers basic facilities, with hot water provided in buckets, but these simple conditions add to its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by chance while climbing. After being flown close to the top of a glacier and climbing to the peak, we had to walk down. To my surprise, we found this hotel at the bottom, set in stunning, wild countryside. Arriving tired and battered to find such luxury, with a pianist playing Cole Porter, was an unforgettable experience.

**C. MAURITIUS - Paradis Hotel**  
On the southwest coast of Mauritius, Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel winds along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. Although the hotel is large and offers many free water sports, you can easily find solitude on its nine kilometers of private beach. Swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, and the hotel will be hidden behind palm trees. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the peacefulness as the sun sets.

**D. ST LUCIA - Ladera Hotel**  
Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has one of the most stunning views in the Caribbean. It is quiet and located at an altitude of 1,000 feet, with open rooms that look out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel features colonial-style decor, with mahogany and greenheart wood furniture, and four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
The Splendid Hotel, located on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, is an ideal escape from the noise of Istanbul. Just an hour by boat, the islands are beautiful and car-free, with horse-drawn carriages and charming wooden buildings. The hotel, painted white with red domes, is inspired by a historic hotel on the French Riviera. Although it is a bit worn down, it still retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with swans. This chateau, which was recently a family home, has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, along with complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is a rare find in Africa, offering comfort without excessive luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers recovering from safaris and planning their next adventure. Guests often arrive, see the beautiful gardens and inviting rooms, and decide to stay longer. The hotel has spacious grounds and buildings on Nairobi Hill, providing a peaceful escape from the busy city. It’s a great place to enjoy an African sunset while sipping beer and looking forward to a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed into by the Duke of Windsor, and since then, many famous people have visited, including Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy guests, but the hotel, which was once a monastery, remains splendid. It offers simple yet delicious food and features beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

**Text:**

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector who evaluates hotels for her job. Christopher Middleton observed her during an inspection. Just one minute into the annual check, problems are already starting for the Globe Hotel, although the staff are unaware of it. The receptionist is busy giving room rates over the phone to a potential guest and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue quietly comments, "She hasn't even acknowledged us. Very poor." This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. She notes that the Globe Hotel is not just an ordinary three-star hotel; it has three red stars, which means it is among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide she works for. 

However, even before they receive a cold welcome, the atmosphere feels off. The entrance from the car park is through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor to the hotel entrance. Sue remarks, "This is not what I expected." 

Things get worse when the receptionist informs them, "We have no record of your booking," in a cheerful tone. It turns out that out of the hotel's 15 rooms, 12 are empty that night. One room is on the top floor, but Sue finds it stuffy and notices a large hole in the wall behind the wardrobe. Early in her career, she earned a reputation for being tough, and she recalls being called "The Woman in Black," even though she never wore black and didn't think she was that tough.

The next morning, after paying her bill, Sue reveals her identity to the hotel’s general manager, Robin Greaves. He looks terrified. Before she says anything, he apologizes for a bad smell in the main lounge, explaining, "We think there's a blocked drain." Sue kindly suggests that he should also instruct his staff to be more careful about showing guests to that lounge. Greaves nods and takes notes, looking worried. He has only been at the Globe for five months and struggles to believe Sue when she says her feedback is meant to help the hotel in the long run.

Not everything is negative, though. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, who provided information about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner also meets the standards to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating, which encourages Greaves to ask, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue responds, "Don’t serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves’ hopeful expression fades.

Sue’s job is to express the complaints that many customers are too afraid to voice. She recalls a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired, but all Sue could say was that he served her apple pie with his fingers. She often receives letters with false accusations, which can be hurtful, but she has learned to expect them.

Sue must not only share her findings verbally with the hotel manager but also send a detailed written report, as the hotels pay for her evaluations. Despite the challenges, being recognized with red stars makes it worthwhile. It is good news for Greaves that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. However, the bad news is that another inspector will return in the next two months to ensure that improvements have been made. Greaves smiles weakly and says, "We'll look forward to that."

**Seven Summits: Doug Scott's Climbing Journey**

Doug Scott, an experienced mountaineer, shares his incredible experiences of climbing the highest peaks on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He began this journey later in life and will describe each mountain in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
While resting in a snow cave 91 meters below the summit, Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, had a strange conversation about sleeping bags, even though they were alone. Doug thought this was due to a lack of oxygen. He started talking to his own feet, which were getting cold, reminding him of climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug reflected on their time on the summit ridge and felt grateful to have Dougal with him, as he inspired confidence. Doug focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit, which he successfully did.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Considered one of the most dangerous mountains, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier in April 1976. They spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day, they realized how challenging their climb would be. They followed a route established in 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. They climbed with all their gear on their backs, which was a first for this area. After facing tough conditions, including a wet sleeping bag and strong winds, they finally reached the summit, feeling victorious.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite planned to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro due to a free ride. They got lost in the dense jungle, which was concerning because water was scarce. On the second day, they found a trail marked by arrows and some litter, leading them to a rock pool. They attempted a direct climb but faced falling rocks and ice, so they wisely chose a different route to reach the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca and met fellow climber Phil Erscheler. Phil suggested they join his group to climb Aconcagua via the Polish Glacier, avoiding the busy standard route. After waiting out bad weather, they set off. The glacier was icy and challenging, so they decided to take the north ridges instead. They joined many others on the standard route and reached the summit just before dark.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be funded by guiding others. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never set, creating a unique atmosphere. On December 7, they set out for the summit. Despite strong winds and freezing temperatures, they all reached the top within eight hours, although visibility was poor due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg and traveled to Terskol, near Elbrus. After acclimatizing, they took a cable car to 3,900 meters and then walked to a refuge at 4,200 meters. Two days later, they faced strong winds while climbing. They thought they had reached the summit but discovered there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and descended the volcano the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their expedition to Carstensz, Doug and his team aimed to create a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about potential dangers from bandits but decided to proceed. On May 12, they began climbing, and as the weather improved, two team members moved ahead while Doug and Sham took their time. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a standing ovation for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**

Style influences many aspects of our lives today, from clothing to home decor and accessories. Jo Foley shares some of the fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to steer clear of traditional, stiff designs and overly frilly styles, opting instead for simpler looks. Ingham has been sketching and designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he attended fashion school, where he learned how to cut and make clothes. However, you don’t need to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening gowns in modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a timeless navy-blue summer suit, a staple in women's wardrobes throughout the 20th century, but he gives it a fresh, contemporary twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail previously worked for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery design. She began creating her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to start her own design business in 1990. Now, her jewellery is popular among many celebrities. Her signature style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has started using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Just four years after launching her career in the competitive fashion industry, Lily Grimson has had two of her designs chosen for a major exhibition. Despite only taking an introductory art and design course, her bags always attract attention. All of Grimson's handbags are handmade in the UK. They are not just practical; they exude glamour, whether made from luxurious calfskin or rich silk. The combination of style and quality makes a Grimson bag truly special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He understands that most women want a natural look that they can manage at home. His unique approach ensures that clients don’t look like they just left a salon. However, this relaxed style comes at a price—£250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Leveraging his celebrity status, Peter has created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, allowing those who can’t visit his salon to achieve their desired looks at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and also works as a consultant for a large supermarket chain, providing floral ideas for top restaurants. Remarkably, she has no formal qualifications in floristry and left her teaching job ten years ago to pursue a new path. Her modern and simple floral arrangements have won numerous design awards, helping her establish her own London Flower School. She has also enjoyed successful lecture tours in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements today should be simple yet striking, avoiding excessive leaves, which can be too large and overpowering. For wedding bouquets, she emphasizes that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin has been created after extensive research into what customers want and nearly two years of work converting four large 18th-century houses. This approach has allowed the hotel to incorporate the latest technology for the benefit of both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to keep track of their preferences. This system helps the hotel provide a special experience for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common complaint among hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will particularly appreciate the technology in their rooms. MacCann estimates that about 65% of the hotel's business will come from this market. To meet their needs, the hotel has transformed the traditional business center into individual rooms equipped with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing facilities.

Given the rapid pace of technological change, the hotel has prepared for future upgrades by installing extra cables. They rent televisions instead of buying them, allowing for easy replacement with newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated as needed.

Despite all this advanced technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished bedrooms that are both cozy and inviting. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

As with all luxury hotels, the food must be exceptional. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who already had two Michelin stars for his Dublin restaurant, has moved his business to the Merrion. This move has allowed him to design a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant on-site is a great advantage with minimal financial risk. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the plants I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to create detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting gradually. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and it's a hectic time," she says. However, she finds beauty in the gradual decay of the flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in, put them in water, and after a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always had a passion for plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in florists. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, which seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in their native places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**No Title**

In March, strong storms caused many trees in the Brackham area to fall. The town lost two large lime trees from the old market square. This change upset many residents who preferred the town's traditional look. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have shared their frustration. However, during the storm, he was too unwell to notice anything. For the first time, he was seriously ill with bronchitis. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. But he believed the police needed him and ignored her advice, trying to continue working. This decision made him forgetful and irritable. Eventually, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor, and he was too weak to argue. Soon after, he got his antibiotics and returned home, where Molly sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen, he struggled to understand. Later that evening, he weakly asked if their house was damaged and felt relieved to hear it was not. He then covered himself with sheets. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics worked and his fever went down, that he noticed the walnut tree's absence had changed the living room's appearance. 

The Pelhams lived in a large house with a big garden, which they had bought without regrets. The garden had given them a sense of privacy. However, the storm changed that. Before, the living room had a beautiful view of the walnut tree, which created interesting light patterns and hid the worn furniture they had brought from their old home. Now, without the tree, the room felt harshly bright, revealing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was also unpleasant. The tall house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, now loomed over them with its unattractive purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.

"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham asked his wife weakly. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. "I've been saying this since we moved in. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. It was the year when storms arrived early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall, and within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. This snow almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. However, in the hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. The wind blew fiercely up there, while in our valley, we only felt sudden gusts that made the trees sway, but their branches remained strong.

Despite the inconvenience of the snow and wind, we were more worried about the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by a series of dams built many years ago. Soon, the snow began to melt, and we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These ominous grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we focused on the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder each day. The melting snow was washed away by heavy rain, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and nearing a dangerous level.

Then it happened—after many years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like Niagara Falls as the water surged over the dam and rushed into the stream below. The river seemed furious as the water poured down towards its lower stretches. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream looked wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it, angrily pushing against its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below the dam. Luckily, our hopes were fulfilled as the dam held, and the water began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the huge clouds above the valley and appreciate the river's tremendous power, knowing that our home in the valley is still secure and safe.

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing film articles for this newspaper was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews of novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. This is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also had experience in radio and television. He hired me, but since Tom was not mainly a journalist, he might not have been very careful in choosing his team. 

Initially, Tom wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need specialized knowledge, like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to discuss which topics to cover, and there would be guests to keep the atmosphere friendly. At that time, it felt like a dream to be part of a new newspaper in a competitive market. I even thought it was unlikely that a millionaire would want to help me personally and was pretending to hire me, reflecting my low self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I felt very awkward.

Tom's idea of a team of critics didn’t work out as planned. Although it was a good concept, we didn’t meet as expected, and most communication happened over the phone. It became clear that the public preferred to associate a reviewer with a specific subject, so I decided to focus on film. Without Tom's initial encouragement, we might not have developed the current system, where I write a detailed weekly piece about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t enjoy the typical role of a film critic, which involves reviewing every new release. That routine would quickly make me feel bored, and I would dread going to screenings, thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" 

The freedom I have allows me to expand my arguments or, during a dull week, to create something interesting from little material. But what is my role in the public eye? I believe people choose films based on stars, marketing, or the director. There is also a tendency for viewers to stick to their preferences. It’s rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a critic's opinion. So, if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel responsible for being "right" about a movie, nor do I think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. My job is simply to present an argument. I’m not a judge, and I wouldn’t want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 

A teenager who loves sports is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably female. This is a chance to work with someone who could be an Olympic champion. The partner should be very enthusiastic about distance running (regular 15 km sessions), distance swimming (enjoying winter training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (a love for 100 km rides is helpful). It is essential to be able to do all three activities without taking a break.

Triathlons are becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. They attract large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes who swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. While it may be exciting for spectators, what drives triathletes to push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, who does well in school, give up so much for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears, a young triathlete, has not yet learned the common phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes use when asked about their motivations. She explains, "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike while still wet. Of course, you get cold. After the 40 km bike ride, you have to run 10 km, which feels long when you’re tired. But it’s really fun, and it’s all worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, but she was the only junior participant. Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we found ourselves at the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried during the run." However, she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would end, but I’m afraid that if I stop even once, I would want to stop again."

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it her all, while most people would step off when they realize they can’t go any further. She just kept going."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but I was much slower in cycling. That’s why I’m working hard to improve." She is trying to convince her parents, who will pay £1,300 for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike (which is a special deal with £1,000 off) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, there is a cost to her dedication. Her intense training has made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don’t have a social life," she admits. "I’m not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I do keep in touch with the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times and achievements."

Where will this strong focus lead Melanie? She has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which involves swimming 750 meters, cycling 20 kilometers, and running 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher competitions than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I don’t have anyone my age to train with," she says. It’s interesting, isn’t it?

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her passion for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world filled with passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember this: only collect items you truly love. 

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. Attracted by their shapes and colors, these pebbles were among the first objects gathered for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed; children still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been a collector all my life, gathering everything from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I was sent to a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by others. I was captivated by these items. 

Interestingly, I am not alone in my interest; many adults share this passion. Researchers believe that for some, collecting is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, it is simply a joyful activity. 

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like coconut shell cups and carved ivory beads. Another notable collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned over 4,000 paintings. However, you don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected various items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, with great determination. 

I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, looking at the ruins of my furniture and collection, unsure which loss hurt more.

What fascinates me is how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet adds value to items traded in markets. As certain objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now considered valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I regret throwing away both the boxes and the toys!)

**My Line of Work**

Four people share their experiences about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I research the exhibition topic and talk to key people to understand the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and images to display and ensure the public can grasp the ideas behind the exhibition. This involves planning interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I also coordinate with engineers and electricians to ensure the exhibition is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I first check the accounts. Then, I prepare new maps and documents to help students learn the routes needed to pass the London taxi-driver test. By midday, around 50 students are in class, figuring out the best routes, including one-way streets and turns. I step in when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. As they approach the test, I give them a simple route but challenge them to find alternatives when roads are closed. This encourages them to think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and mostly work from home. My job involves answering phone inquiries, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. I occasionally visit our main office, but I mainly work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about marine life. I take them out to sea to help them understand the underwater environment better, which often changes their perspectives. I feel fortunate because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means I constantly seek funding, which limits what I can achieve.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite diverse. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain a stock of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. Working with a dedicated team makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there is too much administration, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**No Title**

Every June, we traveled to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It’s a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did so very tastefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us by seeing an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to promote it. One evening, he suggested it and read the details to us. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was a disappointment because the food was terrible.

The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, although my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is probably why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it’s a funny coincidence.

“Welcome back,” Mrs. Malseed said, smiling as she greeted us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. “Arthur, take the luggage up,” she instructed the old porter. She referred to our rooms by the names of flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Instead of numbers, Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors. In winter, when few guests come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of small details like that, while her husband handles repairs and redecorating.

“Welcome, welcome!” Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. He greeted us in the Irish way, smiling broadly with his twinkling brown eyes, making us feel special, not just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was perfect. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. “You look younger every year!” she said, making everyone laugh again.

Arthur led us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play too long because we were still tired from our journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other guests at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the cliff path to the beach. 

In the morning, we planned to walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this routine well because over the years, we had developed this pattern. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in traditional wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a great way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. After having her own breakfast, she prepares breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. By 9:30 a.m., after the guests have finished eating, she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By around 11 a.m., she is ready to ski, taking advantage of the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes starting the next day in a messy space. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful," she notes, while acknowledging that some weeks are more challenging.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start their night at a place called Bananas, then might visit G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar. However, she avoids staying out too late on Saturdays because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, especially when she has to cook breakfast with a headache.

On Sundays, she starts work earlier, preparing breakfast for guests leaving by 7 a.m. Once they leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast and changing beds to get everything ready for new guests. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new arrivals, who usually come around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which she finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it's time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but if she's too tired, she prefers to go to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she claimed to be six years older. One day, she visited his factory wearing overalls and large shoes, with her curly hair framing her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

Several times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed particularly serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to learn how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how fascinated Marie had been by the steam-heated brass hands used to shape the gloves, which she called "pancake hands."

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?"
