He explained, "They go to the tannery first. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"You should visit one if you want to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. Tanneries are basic places. The technology has improved, but they still look similar to how they did hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; they found 6,000-year-old tanning relics in Turkey. The first clothing was just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father is a leather expert; you should talk to him. If you mention gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers are passionate about their work."

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" he asked.

"I can't say I have," she replied.

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child."

He laughed, enjoying her spirit and eagerness to learn. Rita reminded him of Marie, who was much taller and fairer but shared the same bright intelligence. 

"I have an idea," he said. "We will take you through the entire glove-making process. Come on! We’re going to make you a pair of gloves, and you’ll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often travels around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss, but there is one small issue—she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde, which felt too cramped with its small windows. When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London, handling routine tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning itineraries, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group’s manager led to her working behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he prefers caddying, especially since golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, with average earnings between £25,000 and £35,000, much of which goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You're not just carrying bags; you're giving advice, using your knowledge, and trying to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He compiles and analyzes statistics from the caddies' scorecards, which are valuable to television commentators, golf magazines, and the players themselves.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to taste food at top restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. Having been a farmer, I knew about the problem of chickens being killed by a fox, so I wrote a story called *The Fox Busters*, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard at them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don’t wake up at dawn, though. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop, which I dislike. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but I now have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Surrounding it were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that reached down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down." Without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted, calling them cowards to encourage them to join him.

Still laughing, he watched as they hesitated on the roof, looking scared. One by one, they jumped down, relieved to land safely. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes until one of them suggested going back up to the roof to jump again. Although they were not very excited, they climbed back up and began jumping off in a determined way. Soon, only Michael was left on the roof, while the others grinned up at him, urging him to jump. 

Michael wanted to join them but stayed at the edge, nervously licking his lips and smiling foolishly, wondering why the drop seemed so much longer this time. At first, they thought he was just joking, but then they noticed him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, but when that didn’t work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. As time passed, the boys grew tired of waiting and started to shout at him, calling him a coward and asking if he planned to stay up there all night. When he still didn’t move, they began to walk away, still teasing him.

"Who started this?" he called after them. But he remained on the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He stayed there alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone.

He arrived so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home on time by now. If you can’t, maybe you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a hint of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. Although she spoke firmly, Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her. He was still thinking about the grinning faces of his friends and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change their careers are turning to career advisers. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. After this, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggested career options and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest career advice organizations. Taking the career test felt like being back in a science exam. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that this was not about passing or failing. It was difficult to see how the psychometric tests could accurately reflect who I am. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, although I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are relieved I didn’t become a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean making a huge shift. Last March, after losing her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney sought help from Career Analysts. She said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to step back and review my career. I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But in the end, I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities," she explained. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she decided to use her existing skills and move into a field that suited her better than insurance. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, all of whom are satisfied.

Not everyone finds career advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I felt lost. I thought a career adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either meant a significant pay cut or required a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself." She felt that if she had shared the same information with a friend, they would have given her similar advice.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental clinic in the center of Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he examines their teeth. Jerome explains, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has worked to create a space where people feel comfortable. For example, he decided not to wear a white coat, as many people link it to pain. His belief is that dental visits should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This approach may surprise many, as most people associate dental visits with discomfort or clinical settings. Jerome believes that if patients feel relaxed and entertained, they will forget their past negative experiences. One of his innovative relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular," he says. During the initial check-up, patients sit comfortably on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while he examines their teeth. The headset then switches to a special camera that gives patients a visual tour of their mouth.

Interestingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit. Another important aspect is that the clinic smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people enter, I want them to experience with all their senses that this is not a typical dentist visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the clinic very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the top priority. For instance, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It may feel a bit unusual at first, but as long as patients are relaxed, it is not painful.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that making things easier for the patient also makes it easier for the dentist," he explains. He believes his patient-focused approach is part of a gradual shift towards a more relaxed style in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly greets him, offers a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently guides him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it’s easy to see why. The clinic feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which originated in South America, is now a multi-million pound global industry. During Easter, British people spend over £230 million on chocolate, with eight percent of all chocolate sales happening at this time. Only Christmas sees more chocolate consumption. 

Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first cultivated by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often mistakenly called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century when they were also referred to as cacoa and cocao beans.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in the Aztec language, Nahuatl. This chocolate drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found it more enjoyable when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but this recipe did not reach the rest of Europe for another hundred years.

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk solids, leading to the creation of milk chocolate.

At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. However, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising that linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a competitor to luxurious French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars per week, prompting manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent marketing strategy is the "extended line," where traditional chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something new.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by those who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master in his craft. He still has many interests, such as paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells. As he shows me around his apartment, he asks, "Tell me if I am boring you." There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is clearly the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I’ve grown so fond of them. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so people could see my art. They even spoke to a gallery owner." This led to a successful exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. Given the high prices—around £2,000 for the ornaments—Cooke seems willing to sacrifice the empty space above his fireplace.

There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else creates work like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

Cooke wishes he had started this art earlier in life, as he feels he could have created even more wonderful things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels physically limited compared to when he began. However, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led to boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own methods and uses materials as he finds them. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains. Yet, the detail, color variations, and symmetry in his work look very intentional.

Cooke's search for beautiful, tiny shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against critics who accuse him of damaging the beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The ones left behind are broken by the sea. I would never collect shells with living creatures in them or dive for them. But once the creatures have left, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work often exceeds the natural beauty of the shells themselves.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer, a 15-year-old model, balances her time between traveling to exciting places and studying for school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares her story.

When I arrived at the agency, the receptionist informed me that Kira would be late. I tried to ignore the negative stereotypes I had heard about models, such as being difficult or vain. I worried about how late she might be—would it be an hour or more? What if she preferred to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she rushed in, she might be in a bad mood and unwilling to talk. 

However, when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, finally arrived, she was smiling, calm, and accompanied by her mother. She wore a simple black dress and trainers, showing no signs of arrogance. Kira was just a friendly, tall, and pretty girl. Since models under 16 must have an adult with them, her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was there too.

Kira seemed a bit confused by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. "She saw the competition and told me to join," Kira recalled. "I said no, but she sent in some photos anyway." When she learned she was a finalist, she was at school. This achievement boosted her confidence, and she performed well, winning the competition. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to manage her two lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some classmates make rude comments about her success, saying she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this difficult to handle, especially since she is not self-important. "They think that because I became a model, I can't stay the same. The only change is that I am more confident, but not in a bad way. I can stand up for myself more."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't promise to join them because I don’t know my schedule. I can’t make plans, and sometimes they get canceled, but my friends understand. They don’t complain about me being busy with modeling."

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a successful career ahead of her, even before finishing her school exams. As I wrapped up the interview with this remarkable girl, I asked what she would like to do if she didn’t have her beauty. She paused and said, "I’d like to do what you’re doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

They have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their journey began when Terence read about gold worth millions hidden in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While studying 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the most promising land to explore. After clearing away plants and discovering pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. Having spent their savings on this dream, they need to convince an investor to contribute £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they are successful, it could bring more visitors here, but I hope millions of people don’t come and disturb the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It’s adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I’ll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she descends into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration, diving three kilometers down to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are accustomed to these cramped conditions, where they cannot stand or move freely, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last up to 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency and they need to ascend quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. Rachel notes, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel recalls her first experience in the vehicle. She climbed in on a ship's deck with an instructor, who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a confined space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands, where there is a large area of underwater volcanoes releasing black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the impact of a multinational program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on the 'black smokers,'" another term for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel describes a frightening moment during her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment with a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were overwhelmed with relief— they were still alive!

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD, and seeing them in person was an incredible experience."

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign train schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I told myself as I returned home. I repeated this promise the following year and the year after that. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month.

Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. Carrying all your belongings in a rucksack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that have become too dirty or getting rid of books after reading them. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail experience, where common sense can be set aside along with your paperback and socks. All it takes to feel this freedom is one of those tickets in your hand. A system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is quite special.

On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize the full potential of this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too appealing, as there was always another country just beyond the border. And the extra miles? They cost us nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We focused on the most accessible sights, enjoying the chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station.

We were just trying to get by and have fun, just like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from experiencing a place that was once just a name. It feels like the city you arrive in didn’t exist until the train pulls into the station, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by witnessing Europe firsthand, observing the changing landscapes and different lifestyles, can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means little until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be so dull. While the train journey may not reveal new discoveries about the world, it offers a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail provides the best chance to appreciate this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away.

Text: 'There is nothing more frustrating than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in inappropriate clothing. Although airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is a common issue that frequent travelers will eventually face. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially when your journey involves changing planes.

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to switch between two flights, and these times are also extended to allow for luggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which can disrupt the baggage system. Human error or accidents, such as a destination label getting torn off, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For instance, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million of them changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to transfer between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-haul flights).

Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have their bad days. The risk of losing luggage during plane changes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is particularly known for luggage going missing when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America.

To reduce the chances of losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all legs of your journey. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, muddy browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a peaceful atmosphere, much like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, leaving a strong impression even after it disappears in an instant. 

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep affection for this small bird is shown by his uncertainty about what exactly attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is said to be a moon goddess who transformed into a bird. Another story claims that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Despite the various shades of blue in their feathers, kingfishers do not have any blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. Their vibrant colors, combined with the fact that these birds are shy but can be observed from a distance, create a perfect opportunity for photographers. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he draped over himself while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to capture his first good photograph. During this time, the European kingfisher became a major part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream rich with kingfishers, but school limited his time with the birds. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Nevertheless, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then became an assistant to the editor, and eventually worked as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I’m drawn to a simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still captivate him. His photographs convey some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever express.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from New Conductors**

Giving directions to an orchestra is a challenging task. Anne Inglis interviews five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, had a unique opportunity when she asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous; I have always felt confident in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a significant competition in 1991 after two unsuccessful attempts. Looking back, he feels fortunate about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I might have been forgotten." The competition opened many doors for him, including a position as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being labeled as a competition winner: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned." Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him after the competition, are inviting him back. "If that doesn't happen, my career could suffer."

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. A turning point for her was starting lessons with Sian Edwards. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size, unlike the larger conductors I had learned from before. This made a big difference." Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, noting, "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, describes his journey into conducting as surprising but fascinating. He began as a resident musician at an opera house and learned from skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's *Agrippina* from the piano at a festival, which was a new experience for him. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and had a clear vision of how I wanted it to sound. I tried my best to achieve that. Thankfully, people respect my overall musical ability. I draw from all my past experiences, both in musical style and performance. Now, I am open to any opportunities to discover what I enjoy."

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and recommended him to his agent. Now 32, Marshall found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He had to manage some relaxed professional musicians who were reading newspapers during the performance. "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best results. Many orchestral musicians I’ve encountered don’t seem to need much guidance from a conductor. But I’m not afraid to express my needs. If people see you’re anxious, it only makes things worse. I have never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to do it, but I have received kindness from others. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is also a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides, like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use a better atmosphere and nicer scenery. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could explore! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, which looked like it would get you wet, but it didn’t. For younger children, Toy Land was a lot of fun. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. When I couldn’t sit with both girls on one ride, a staff member kindly offered to accompany one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I’m not very brave, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t try the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it less exciting, but they were the right age and enjoyed it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we definitely felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie found the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on multiple times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We noticed that the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World, and we wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Since she had experience with computers, her husband encouraged her to start this business. Although it required a lot of money and was challenging at first, she managed her finances carefully and communicated with her bank manager about spending. Working from home saves her money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. Her business remains small, and most customers pick up their orders directly.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum. However, after moving to the countryside, she decided to start her own business, creating a collection of 50 cards that she sells to museums. She works in a large room upstairs but finds it hard to focus because there are always household tasks to do, like mowing the lawn. Maggy does not advertise; her business relies entirely on word of mouth. She receives orders from London because her prices are lower than those of other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she believes the benefits of working alone outweigh the drawbacks.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has experienced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. At one point, she employed six full-time curtain-makers, but due to an economic downturn, she had to let them go, which was difficult because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and collaborates with women who work from their homes. Delia has learned to lower her prices when necessary and to explore new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the rural lifestyle. Tessa enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants, but 80% of her income comes from international deals, which means she often takes calls at unusual hours. She finds it challenging to maintain discipline and close her office door. Tessa publishes children's books that reflect various cultures and collaborates with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated because all her professional experience was in London.

E. **Meg Rivers** operates a cakes-by-post business and a shop that generates £250,000 a year, employing six people, some of whom work part-time. She started her business ten years ago from home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. After receiving requests from friends and family, she began shipping cakes across the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where all the baking is done, employing a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg no longer bakes herself, as she now manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as she did not have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they have musicians and an instrument maker. John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their son Paul, who was ten years old at the time. However, they found that cellos were very expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years.

After making several violins and violas, John finally made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers that it turned out great. John later made another cello for Paul, which he used until recently. John has now retired from teaching and works full-time as a craftsman, making about twelve violins each year. One of his violins was sold to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo, which was a big achievement for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother Huw were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano: "As soon as I could reach the keys, I played," he recalls. Eventually, he was drawn to the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin because John played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. Paul tried the violin for a short time but preferred the cello after being inspired by a cellist in his father's group.

Huw, now 22, also found his own path in music as a pianist and composer. He appreciated the support from his parents and felt motivated by Paul's achievements rather than pressured.

Paul has had great success with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until recently when he borrowed a 304-year-old cello by Francesco Rugeri from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul jokes that his father's cello might need many years to develop the same sound quality as the Rugeri.

Soon, Paul will perform on television, playing Elgar's Cello Concerto. He believes that his performance will be unique, regardless of the piece's famous history. However, he won't be able to watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, one of the wardens who helps care for the beautiful areas owned by the Trust.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. "You are always interacting with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies," he explains. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. Around 80 people applied for the position of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. Gareth got the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he did not have formal training. 

He finds it helpful to still farm with his parents, as it allows him to relate to farmers and understand their challenges. "They can't fool me!" he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical aspects of the job, such as building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers, butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests as a child. Recently, he wondered where he could find those things now. He realizes that farming has changed the countryside, but he believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. Both groups wanted things done their own way. Now, they are communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. "We are at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," Gareth says. 

Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to ensure tasks are completed efficiently and with minimal fuss. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork," he explains. 

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. However, he admits that some visitors can be frustrating. "Some people come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to them can be annoying!" he says. 

In the end, Gareth believes it all comes down to common sense. If you have plenty of that and enjoy working outdoors, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just don’t expect a position to open up in the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slowinski, the captain of England's netball team. When I spoke with her, she was busy preparing for the World Championships next month. Her day included teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people stared at her while she trained. She replied, "I’m so focused on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slowing down out of the corner of my eye, but that’s it."

Kendra explained, "My entire life right now is about being at my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to get as fit as possible." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it promises to be the largest yet, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always won against them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." Currently, the England team is ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra warns that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only get one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard just to lose. But once the game is over, we become friends again." 

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It’s crucial that we all think and train like world-class players. As captain, I believe it’s important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra mentioned, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned everything carefully. I decided a while ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she will probably have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents might not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help academically gifted children, musically talented kids often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who show musical talent, especially those encouraged by their parents or teachers, can benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to develop their musical skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend a significant part of their day—between one third and one half—on music-related activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is dedicated to a limited academic curriculum, focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with smaller class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some drawbacks. One major issue is the cost, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 a year for boarders. Each school tries to help families with scholarships and financial aid for exceptionally talented children. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some children may lose their musical abilities during their teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic focus, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before pursuing a specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted may thrive in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a standard school routine with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, along with orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the plants I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to create detailed studies of individual plants instead of painting the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants together, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes, it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and it's a hectic time," she says. However, she finds beauty in the gradual decay of the flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, and after a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in florists. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, but they thrive just as well as they did in their original homes, like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never finished, as Sarah Sutherland-Pilch explains to Veronica Lee. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. Known as Pilch, she works for a company in Val d'Isère, France, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She sees being a chalet girl not as a career but as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can accommodate up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she considers the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep, as she believes it would be a mistake. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she notes. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week wonderful. Breakfast this morning was great fun, but some weeks don’t go as well for various reasons."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. "We often start at Bananas, then might go to G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar," she explains. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day when you really don’t want to be cooking breakfast while feeling exhausted," she admits.

On Sundays, work starts earlier than usual, as breakfast for the guests must be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We just blitz the place—clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready." If she hasn’t done the shopping for the week on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests, who usually arrive around 4:30 p.m. "Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them," she says.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps any guests who need boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and getting a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at the offices of Marie Claire magazine. "Choosing what to wear for my day at Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a still-life photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm and peaceful place, and here I was rushing around when I could have been quietly cuddling an animal. Some members of the fashion team seemed quite stressed, but my job is not very pressuring. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I found it funny to think that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines operate, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I was petting one of the elephants, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had such a wonderful day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening program Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I enjoyed being outside because, depending on my shifts, I sometimes don’t see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was a lot of fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My romantic idea of landscape gardening didn’t include hard physical work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective as a gardener, so I don’t plan to quit my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medication. I thought I might faint while doing some tasks, but I surprised myself by managing well. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is not as meaningful as nursing. My day at the hospital was not exactly pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as a cabin crew member. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt completely different—people started to look up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked to us about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I already knew from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as possible. There is a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past stunning seascapes. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the most beautiful gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking views.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On that train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey itself was wonderful, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unpredictable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train finally arrived, it was a rush of people climbing into and onto the carriages, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are children, but that’s not my story. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, well-maintained section of the line cared for by volunteers. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Are you trying to get your story published? If you’re unsure where to send it, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Who should I send it to?" One important thing to understand is that you need to research your target markets and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. 

No matter what type of writing you do, it’s essential to know the markets you want to reach. One of the best ways to do this is by reading as much relevant material as you can. Visit your local library and explore nearby bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

Keep in mind that this knowledge needs to be updated regularly since new publications are always coming out, editors change jobs, and magazines can shift their focus. Publishers are always looking for fresh talent, so as writers, we must provide what they want. 

If you’re unsure about what to write, for example, if you think you might want to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories, as this market is quite limited today. Get recent copies of those magazines and learn about the types of stories they are buying and who their readers are. These readers have specific expectations, and the editor’s job is to meet those needs.

Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it’s likely that the work isn’t ready for publication. I try to give honest feedback while remaining positive. The issue is that many new writers are too eager to submit their work before they are truly ready. If you’ve only written one story or article, it’s very unlikely to get published. This is rare. 

When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have years of experience in publishing or journalism behind them. Once you send out your work for the first time, start writing more while you wait for a response—write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence and fluency. Instead of discarding any of your work, focus on improving it. 

I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before achieving success. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby, or consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The usual clean and bright atmosphere of the station felt lost. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students scattered their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me, who had long blond hair. I had thought about talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, northbound, yes," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" 

"No, New York, but I'll be..." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said, moving to the next bench. Now I was paying full attention. He asked an old lady, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said, "Wilmington," he just walked on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. I understood why he didn’t ask me; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He seemed stressed now. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five—older than me. A schoolteacher type. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets on leashes. 

Then I heard the man talking. "My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn’t know what to do." The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see where this was going. 

"So I told her to stay put in the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." I thought this was a strange story. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? 

"Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a simple envelope, but a padded one, the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. I thought silently, "Watch yourself, lady."

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, shares his thoughts about his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. John believes that everyone has a chance in life. For him, that chance was to run a restaurant, while Gary's was to pursue cooking. When John learned about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it, even though it was in poor condition. He felt it was just right for his plans.

Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembered feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. This made him value family time. His wife took care of their children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made it a point to have meals together, which helped their children, Gary and Joe, grow up confident. From a young age, they would interact with regular customers, giving them a strong start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath, thinking it was a swimming pool, and accidentally knocked himself out. As he grew older, he earned pocket money by doing small jobs. By the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he always had money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before John. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John enjoyed seeing Gary contribute.

Although Gary was not very academic, he excelled in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John realized that Gary had a talent for catering. When Gary needed to do work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one goal at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told Gary that he needed to achieve his goals by the age of 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary attended catering college. On his first day, while other students struggled, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his tasks in just an hour. He even helped his classmates. John is amazed by how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become and feels very proud of him. He has always encouraged Gary to work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. Gary has recognized the opportunities he has and has taken full advantage of them.

As parents, we hope our children listen to us. John feels satisfied knowing that even if Gary only remembers a small part of their conversations, he has learned valuable lessons.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was very difficult, like searching for gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections. If you knew someone who knew someone else who was moving out, that often helped. But for Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, she had no such connections. She didn’t know anyone who could tell her about a vacant room. Instead, she had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. To Jo, Dublin felt like a big unknown. She felt nervous as she took the train to start her new job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school just assumed she would leave. Who would want to stay in a small, remote town? That’s all she had heard for years. Her friends wanted to escape, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm, as they were often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. However, Jo was unaware that they were still talking about her while she responded to an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her workplace and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive. There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary—just a red-brick terraced house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down.
