Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully, as you should plan to stay in it for two to three years. Future employers will closely examine this job when you apply for your next position. It should demonstrate that you have thought seriously about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and increase your responsibilities.

If you feel the urge to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can take temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. She describes it as the perfect first job because they were supportive, and she learned how to navigate an office and improve her word processing skills. However, there was no opportunity for advancement, so she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really evolved. From the start, my boss was eager to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I began, but my responsibilities have changed. I have moved from mainly typing and answering calls to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. I also manage various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes me in all her work and assigns me specific projects and events to organize."

**Text: 'What is the Secret of Confident People?**

Confident people often seem like they were born that way, but many say it is a skill they learned over time. Nina Hathway interviews five individuals to find out how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At around twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I was nervous but ended up doing well, and someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I felt very anxious, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school was a turning point that helped me in many areas of my life.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became overly aggressive and impatient, thinking that was how confident people acted. Eventually, I learned that true confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work becomes too overwhelming, I don’t feel guilty about postponing some tasks. When facing challenges, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can undermine confidence, so I often have quiet conversations with myself to overcome those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as very confident, but the calmer I appear, the more nervous I actually feel. I had to learn to look confident because it is crucial in television. Interviewing people made me realize that most of us feel tense in important situations, but we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mother once told me, during my teenage worries about fashion, that everyone is too busy thinking about themselves to notice me. I find this advice very helpful. I also believe that facing your fears helps build confidence. I was very nervous during my driving test, but after passing, I felt I could handle anything.

**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am well-liked in the restaurant, but I know that not everyone will like me. I focus on liking myself for who I am, rather than trying to meet others' expectations. My company offers many training courses, which have boosted my self-esteem. They also encourage us to set realistic goals, which helps us see our progress instead of aiming too high and feeling disappointed.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings, afraid to share my opinions. Eventually, I found the courage to speak up. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public before and would shake with nerves. I told myself, 'Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I also found it helpful to write down a few notes to refer to, like a comfort blanket. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking publicly. The real secret to confidence is reminding yourself repeatedly that 'Nothing is impossible.'

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finders can keep it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking out at Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a line of tense competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different kite designs, which were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 

"Flying kites isn't too hard," Adnan said, "but making them requires real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how to do it." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept. At his house, I enjoyed cold milky tea and fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he asked me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't fit it into my plans. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. 

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A narrow boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a footpath into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before starting my hike, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was steep and slippery. However, when I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. 

The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and thousands of creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy raindrops. I also worried about my car being washed away (which sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there at the bottom of the track, covered in mud. 

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their curiosity was friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I will remember it more for the kindness of its people.

What kind of shopper are you? Shopping is something we all do, whether we enjoy it or not. There are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked several people about their shopping habits:

A. Melanie, 22, dancer: "I'm a shopping addict! I love spending money. When I have cash, I go shopping and it makes me happy. I can't resist sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're both addicted!"

B. Brenda, 40, office manager: "I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the grocery shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don’t spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my son and daughter shopping, but we all have different tastes, so it’s not enjoyable. I rarely spend money on myself, and when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I actually did because the real price seems shocking."

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager: "I only shop for essentials. I dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won’t settle for anything else. Shopping is tiring, and I’d rather be doing something else."

D. Anita, 35, TV producer: "I like to browse occasionally, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and prefer to shop quickly. However, I do have some items in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes."

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary: "I really dislike shopping. I can never find what I want or get help. The shops are noisy and messy, which makes it a nightmare for me. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often since I receive most of my clothes as gifts. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and get it done quickly."

F. Lisa, 22, actress: "I’m probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my friends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I’ll buy it."

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant: "I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t go overboard. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much."

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker: "I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too crowded. I consider myself a careful shopper. I have a good idea of what I want and don’t rush into buying things. I check other shops to find better deals, which takes me a long time."

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager: "I’m an unwilling shopper. Working in the city center has made shopping less appealing to me. When I have to shop, I go without trying things on because it’s too much effort. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I prefer to make a few mistakes rather than spend too much time in shops."

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets are available at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer various questions about them. The quiz sheets can be picked up from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Artwork**  
The Gallery now features a beautiful still life by the Dutch painter Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for specific flowers to bloom in different seasons. This artwork was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is currently displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this time: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will focus on Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide selection of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Visitor Information**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours highlight some of the Gallery's most famous paintings and showcase its collection of important European art from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are similar to a gram or a kilometre. The main difference is that you can trade money for goods or services. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of money, known as 'currencies', to make trading easier. Eventually, these different currencies began to connect, which is why today we all use a national currency.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare, as most women at that time had limited chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have any of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical texts. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work. During her time, many rulers feared science, and those involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. They are the only flowering plants that can survive in the extremely cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way.

One of the remarkable features of grass is its ability to recover quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike many other plants, grass grows new leaves from below the soil rather than from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live together in one area. When they eat all the grass in a spot, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh food source.

Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, about her dream of making fashion her career. She believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.

After finishing her degree, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. Although she attended many industry events, she couldn't afford the designer clothes she admired. To solve this, she began making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends noticed her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. This led her to find a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. The clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned, which motivated her to leave her advertising job. She took out a £20,000 loan to start her own womenswear brand.

Kal's parents were supportive of her decision to change careers, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she recently gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels grateful for her success, saying, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in the history of cinema. However, his life has not always been easy. As a child, Tom was shy and struggled to make friends, even though he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, he moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter while also taking drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he had become so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom continues to act in films and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had traveled over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. As it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, Bo's owner was also searching for her. After looking everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.'

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses the entire Australian continent, moving from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but this name is somewhat misleading because the train is known for being late.

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide began in the 1920s, with a line reaching Alice Springs. However, flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished just a few months before my trip. The railway was designed for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. Unlike luxury trains like the Orient Express, the Ghan does not focus on providing luxury, although the food on board is very good. The railway was originally built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to Australia’s southern cities via Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent.

It is rare for a transcontinental railway to be completed, and the Ghan claims to be the first north-south railway in the world. As I waited to board, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Many of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners who were especially eager to get on the train. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged anymore, and few people do it. Our group simply walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers choose to stop there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very exciting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. However, on the third day at dawn, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was coming to an end, and although the train did not meet all the expectations set by advertisements, it had taken me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is located in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time. 

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred meters high, making it probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries,' which are large bowl-like areas cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are essential on Ben Nevis because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. 

Even though some members of our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothing. Although the weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, there was still a sense of nervousness when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always challenging. 

As we climbed, my legs felt heavy. Being the least experienced climber, I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes paused to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start climbing again. I promised myself that I would train properly before my next climb. 

After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. This path is only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops steeply on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. Unfortunately, we were not so lucky, as a mist had rolled in. 

Getting back down to camp can be just as difficult as climbing up. You need to be able to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. It was only when I was safely in the tent that I could say I truly enjoyed the experience. But at least I made it to the top.

**Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, similar to our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The construction took several months, and we watched it all happen. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, even though it meant some beautiful open space was lost. The noise from the construction machines was quite loud, and the builders often had to stop working because of heavy rain. At times, we worried that the building would never be completed.

Now, we have five large classrooms, much bigger than those in our old school, which was very old. We also share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is a nursery, a lovely dining room, and spacious changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the warmth comes from everyone inside—the students, teachers, and the computers we use. The building is designed to keep the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof, as it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for our lights and computers comes from a wind turbine located on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very quickly. It is so large that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures that we plan to share on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being completed. For example, we are currently preparing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers believe we will learn much faster now that we are here!

A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation was not great, but it had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn were with Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area well. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we were unsure of the exact activities. Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I started with caving. Climbing out was more difficult than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally made it out—covered in mud but happy and excited about our adventure.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late to do anything. I felt worried because I am 72 years old and far from home. I stood by the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what had happened, and he kindly gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he told me I could keep the fare. I made it home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that operated the bus where I left my handbag. He informed me that they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me.

I was amazed to get my handbag back with everything inside still there. I want to express my gratitude to everyone who helped me that day. Their kindness and honesty meant a lot to me.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are among the most intimidating animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they prey on. 

While sharks share some similarities with other fish, their bodies are quite different. For instance, most sharks must keep swimming constantly to breathe and survive, which means they hardly ever sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can become completely still. This is a useful method for researchers who need to study sharks, as it helps them learn more about these intriguing creatures.
