Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St. Petersburg, Russia. On my first day of ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone surrounded me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and they switched to English, so we were able to communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very friendly, my Russian has improved a lot, and I can understand my teachers.

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mother stayed with me, and I felt a bit sad when she left. I even called home late one night because I was feeling lonely. The classes in Russia are much harder than those in my ballet school in England, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This gives me confidence to meet the school’s high standards.

In the evenings, I like to watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish. Now that I have settled in, I feel at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was extremely cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the locals said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Currently, we are preparing for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very lucky to be here.

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular summer destination to experience the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, it was decided that the dark and cold winter could be seen as a positive feature. In the winter of 1990, French artist Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a structure made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors to the area. One night, a group of foreign guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous worldwide.

As winter begins, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to construct the hotel for that year. As each section is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first section is completed in December, and each week after that, a new section opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outdoors using natural winter materials, the completion date depends on the weather, so plans can change.

In spring, as temperatures rise, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature stays between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothing, such as warm overalls, hats, and gloves, as part of their stay. It is also wise for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks, and to choose shoes that are slightly larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items along with your booking, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store because of many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (available only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (available only from 3 am to 8 am). The store's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had planned to stay open for the first 24 hours without closing. Unfortunately, it had to shut down just half an hour after opening.

A police officer who was called to the scene said, "We knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly for their turn. Another issue was that there was a long line of cars trying to enter the parking lot. I was shocked to see many people leave their cars in the middle of the road and walk the last few meters to the store, which completely blocked the road."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who managed to enter the store, said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were very calm and explained the situation. They had no choice; it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Membership**

The Short Story Society aims to support writers in Britain today. Founded in 1899, it is now one of the most active arts organizations in the country.

**Society Magazines**

We publish several excellent magazines, including the well-known *Short Story Review*. This magazine features short stories from some of Britain's best writers and offers many chances for new writers to get their work published. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, includes interviews with writers and provides information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing community. You can find a selection of articles from recent issues by following the links on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and older, and stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members must pay £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The overall winner will receive a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**

For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, providing children and teachers with new ideas and helping them gain confidence in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe serves as the social hub of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is perfect for browsing the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in the heart of London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members receive discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members from around the world, and anyone aged 18 or older is welcome to join. If you are interested in becoming a member of The Short Story Society, please click here and fill out a registration form.

**Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on just one breath of air. In 2003, she made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters into the ocean and return to the surface without assistance. Although she had previously dived deeper, she used a balloon to help her come back up then. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man.

A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. After several serious accidents involving other divers, some people argue that free-diving is too dangerous. However, Tanya disagrees, emphasizing that safety and training are the most important aspects of the sport.

Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya maintains a consistent training schedule. Two-thirds of her training is done in the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking to build her stamina.

When preparing for dives, Tanya usually travels away from home. She aims to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, taking a rest day between each dive to avoid fatigue, which could affect her performance.

When not training, Tanya often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects and films. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she spent her childhood swimming and exploring rock pools to observe sea life. Tanya feels that her life now reflects her childhood dreams. Because she is well-known in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she discusses environmental issues.

Looking to the future, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and is eager to emphasize that she does not plan to retire from the sport anytime soon.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few restrictions. If you can draw something, you can animate it for the cinema. New ideas and advanced computer programs are making cartoons exciting for people of all ages. By the late 1970s, the film industry believed that cartoons were only for children. However, soon after, a few directors introduced original ideas. They showed that it was possible to create films that both adults and children could enjoy together. Not every cartoon film was a success, though. For instance, *The Black Cauldron* did not do well because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this experience, and film companies started to earn a lot of money again.

New TV Star Caroline Benson shares her experience with her first TV role. 

"I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to adapt the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to audition for the role. My mother was surprised at first, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the role. 

Filming started a week after the term began, so I asked the university for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends about the filming, but they found out and thought it was exciting. It was an incredible experience, and I feel very lucky. After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. Although I’m not from an acting family, my grandfather was an opera singer. I have auditioned for other TV roles but haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I felt a bit lost. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I’m going to Greece for the summer with friends."

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a fast-growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is shared in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. 

This is not a typical business book, nor is it solely about my life. The key message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can make a positive impact. In both business and life, I want to feel joy, a sense of family, and excitement from unexpected events. I have always wanted my employees at 'The Body Shop' to share these feelings.

Now, this book spreads my ideas to the world and makes them public. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' or to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. On the ship, which has air conditioning, you will find a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and arrive in Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After a morning of sightseeing in Oporto, you will return to the ship and set off for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue your journey up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine production. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drinks.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that was once a palace, featuring a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Afterward, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return trip to Tua will be by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then sailing down the river to Oporto. You will spend the night on board the Lady Ivy May.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with enough time for sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid created by bees. It is made up of water and sugars. To make just half a kilo of honey, bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers. The color and taste of honey vary depending on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred different types of honey. Generally, lighter-colored honey has a milder flavor compared to darker honey.

In ancient times, honey was the main source of sweetness because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey highly and even used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed all over the world. Research indicates that honey can help reduce tiredness and enhance athletic performance. Additionally, honey is not only a food; it can also be used to soothe sore throats and is included in many skin and hair care products.

**Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a significant center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be recognized as a city and to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second largest city in England. For the next 300 years, it continued to grow and prosper, becoming known for having as many churches as there are weeks in a year and as many pubs as there are days. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. The city has a growing student population and is a modern commercial center, being the largest hub for insurance services outside London.

Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and several arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', which wears green and yellow, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's recent developments is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, residents dealt with a large construction site in the city center as builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a park on the roof of the Mall, complete with beautiful water features and many trees. Fortunately, the old open market remains in the city center, next to the new development. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich successfully combines its rich history with modern growth.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that happens every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the city. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected to participate at its current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The pilots communicate with each other via radio and light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This event is called "balloon glows," and it offers a great chance for taking beautiful photographs. To see these glows, you should arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 AM, as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in various sizes and colors, with some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, as well as popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Children will especially enjoy this.

In the afternoon, you can experience a balloon flight over the desert by booking a ride with one of the many companies that offer this service. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a stunning view of the festival from above. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates ideal conditions for ballooning. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival entrance. Dress in several layers of light clothing, as it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but you will need sunglasses and sunscreen during the day. Bring a flashlight for nighttime events and, of course, your camera. If you use film instead of digital photography, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and nighttime photos.

The Eden Project

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the most popular tourist attractions in the UK. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere represents a different climate zone, demonstrating the important relationship between people and plants. It is fascinating to see how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters maintain the right temperature for the plants. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid due to a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environments of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone in the near future.

Some people have expressed dissatisfaction with this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. After all, 500 pages of original writing for just £6.99 is quite impressive, isn't it? The majority of the book consists of fiction, including both parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable works by well-known authors like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, many lesser-known writers have focused on food in their pieces. For example, Jane Harris's story, Those Nails, is not something you should read right after eating, as it contains some very disturbing scenes! 

The collection also features excellent contributions from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. Additionally, there are excerpts from novels that are still being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a small section of non-fiction, which includes a humorous article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and a remarkable personal piece by Ursula Owen. Overall, this is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's edition will bring.

**No Title**

Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher, believes that the best age to start learning the violin is between three and six years old. She explains that this is when children are discovering the world around them. Living in London, Margaret usually accepts students who are three or four years old, but she has made exceptions for enthusiastic five-year-olds.

When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class included her children’s five-year-old friends. Margaret teaches in groups, with about twelve students in each class. Each lesson lasts one hour and takes place every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her each week. It is also important for parents to attend these classes, as their involvement is crucial.

From the very first lessons, students learn to play music by ear. They do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years, and there is often a noticeable difference between their playing and their ability to read music. Margaret explains that her teaching method is not designed to create expert violinists. She often advises students who excel to leave and pursue more traditional methods of violin study.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to their previous album, "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD: Tom Wilcott has joined as the new bass guitarist, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Additionally, Tom Simpson is now playing the drums.

From the first song, which is a dance track, it is clear that the band is shifting away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and more energetic. Most of the later songs return to the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks may surprise many fans, but either could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford showcases his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should appreciate that he recorded these songs before experiencing throat issues, which led to the cancellation of their upcoming tour. However, anyone who has bought tickets should not worry, as all concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.

On this CD, Moonshine demonstrates their ability to create great music in different styles, from the familiar slow songs to lively tracks that make you want to dance. I did feel that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not quite as strong. Nevertheless, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and will bring more success to the band.

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a beautiful natural harbor, it was discovered by land instead of by sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest individuals were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill known as Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous attractions like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the former prison.

**SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and interesting look at daily life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys discusses important events of that time, such as diseases, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his own flaws—like often falling asleep in church or admiring pretty girls. He talks about his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they made up, as well as his concerns about her health. 

In addition to reading, Pepys enjoyed music, theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. He was a busy man with many important roles, including being a Member of Parliament and the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not focus on shoes being comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also common, depending on current trends. It was only about one hundred and fifty years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. 

Originally, all shoes were handmade, but now most shoes are produced in large factories using machines, although some shoemakers still use traditional methods. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to create many more shoes at lower prices, making them available to a larger number of people.

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to encourage more women to join the sport, to show them how enjoyable it can be, and to help them feel confident enough to start running. I decided to create a running club for women in my community because I was frustrated with how many race organizers think. They often complain about the low number of women in running but use this as a reason not to provide separate changing rooms.

I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they probably imagined it as painful training. They didn't realize that running could be fun, with chatting and smiling while enjoying beautiful places, like along a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about diet and fitness from other runners. I wanted to contribute to women's running, and it has been a joy to see their progress—almost as much joy as they have experienced themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people moved there hoping to become rich. New towns quickly developed, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska.

During the summer, supplies could be brought to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to reach them. To solve this problem, a winter trail was built in 1910 for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothing to gold miners. This trail became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska, stopping at 'roadhouses' where drivers could find a warm bed and food for themselves and their dogs.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced dog teams and steam boats as the main transport. However, in 1925, the dogs had one last important mission when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The medicine needed to treat the disease was located in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. At that time, airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away on a trip. Therefore, it was decided to transport the medicine using dog teams.

The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail, and took twenty teams just six days to complete. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who had come to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to navigate through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be an excellent guide. The final part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had been driving dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further, preventing the team from falling into icy water. Thanks to their efforts, the diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, around 6,000 tourists visit each year to experience one of Europe’s most unique hotels. In this hotel, everything is made of ice, including the rooms where guests eat, drink, and sleep. You can even have a wedding ceremony there. The bar is also made of ice, so it’s not a good idea to place hot drinks on it!

The bedrooms are kept at about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags that keep them warm in such cold conditions. If needed, the hotel can also provide suitable outdoor clothing. The Ice Hotel lasts for only six months because it melts in the summer, and every winter, it is rebuilt. Constructing the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl on an all-boys football team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized she was very fast. 

"He talked to me about athletics. I didn’t understand at first because I only knew about football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to training. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help improve their financial situation. They agreed to let him take her away for training.

In 1991, Maria accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had previously refused because she was worried about missing her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the stunning views. The view is even more impressive from the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass, allowing visitors to see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of visitors have experienced it. To protect the glass, you must wear special covers over your shoes. Walking on the Skywalk gives you the feeling of floating like a bird high in the air.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch nearly the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest but are also found a few hundred miles from the center in the southern regions. Although the Rockies are not as tall as the Alps, they are still incredibly beautiful. There are many roads that cross the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. 

You can start your journey in Vancouver, which is one of Canada's most beautiful cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes away from the city center. 

In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day for the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains each week, but the journey remains an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you will see some of the most stunning views at night.

**ZOOS**

People have been keeping animals in zoos for over 3,000 years, starting with a large zoo in China called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals were often trained to perform for visitors, but this practice has stopped. Now, the main goal of zoos is to allow people to observe animals in their natural behaviors. Most cities today have a zoo or wildlife park.

However, opinions about zoos vary. Supporters argue that zoos help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close, which would be difficult without them. On the other hand, critics believe it is wrong to confine animals in cages. They argue that poorly managed zoos can lead to animals living in unsanitary conditions and being fed inappropriate food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We may not have looked like professional adult bands, but we were all experienced in competitions, so the quality of our playing was impressive, especially considering our age. Musicians from each band even made up new songs right on stage. It was thrilling to watch, but even more exciting when my band performed!  

Our school has a fantastic jazz band, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half of the applicants. However, anyone eager to play can attend jazz practice before school, and we often hang out after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. We also go on trips to jazz summer camps around the country; I’ve attended a few and learned a lot.  

Many adults are surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher believes it’s because pop music isn’t challenging enough for serious musicians like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music while also feeling connected to its history, as you perform like the great jazz artists before you. Our school is fortunate to have excellent teachers and supportive parents. Without their help, we wouldn’t make much progress in our music!

**Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, rain is rare, and when it does occur, the city's water pipes often cannot handle the sudden floods, causing the streets to become like rivers. Despite the recent dry winters, the local people welcome the rain when it arrives. 

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain; instead, they benefit from a system of underground channels built in the 11th century that brings water from the mountains throughout the year. These mostly dry areas that receive water this way are called oases. 

Traveling south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura, where every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels to grow food. The snow-covered Atlas Mountains in winter create a beautiful backdrop for this area.

**Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always dreamed of being a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. Kath explains, "People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three."

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time work in the circus. They both found jobs with a well-known circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and return home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away.

Kath admits, "I can't say it was easy. There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."

Gareth shares, "People ask about my education, but from the start, someone has always come to teach me wherever we go. I use the same books as my classmates back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind."

What about the future? Kath says, "It was a tough decision, but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? He confidently states, "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency designed for young people aged 8 to 18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. These are sent to major national and local newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles created by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet others and participate in projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide. Since our agency began in 1994, originally called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined. One of them is Sophie. She shares, "I first learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's views on hip hop music. I was in a room with young journalists and was impressed by the opportunities they had. Age didn’t matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I started attending the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and remained a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I ever expected. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, where I check articles written by journalists before they are published online."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and older who teach new members basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often at youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who accompany them on these outings.

Eight-eighteen News offers training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, please call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test required to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here, you will find all the information you need before booking a flight. During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. These flights take you over Antarctica and back. The exact dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the journey, we usually start to see sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctic research stations will give talks about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is also a camera next to the pilot that shows a view from the cockpit throughout the flight.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will be asked to move to the seat indicated on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While we are over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to enjoy the views. The pilot will fly in long 'figure 8' patterns over interesting sights so that everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, our captain will check the satellite images of the clouds and choose the route that offers the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Absolutely! You are welcome to bring all types of cameras. We also offer some fun photo opportunities on board, where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothing.

**Little Chefs**

A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where kids can have fun and learn to make delicious food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it even better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to enjoy the food we've made together." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She shares, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of just staying home on weekends. At first, I wasn't very interested, but I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, explains, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they grow up."

**Winter Driving**

Driving in winter can be dangerous because conditions can change quickly, leading to accidents. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill, and ice can be hidden under melting snow, making it easy to lose control. A car coming towards you might slide unexpectedly.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Think of driving as if you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you; you want to avoid spilling it.

**Rule Number Two** is to stay alert to potential dangers. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Practice how long it takes to stop by braking gently. You might be going faster than you realize. Generally, allow double your usual stopping distance on wet roads, three times that on snow, and even more on ice. Always try to keep control of your car to prevent accidents.

**Craigie Aitchison**

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London with the plan to study law, but instead, he went to art school. He found the traditional drawing classes challenging, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government funded his art studies, and he became fascinated by early Italian artists, which is reflected in some of his artwork. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. 

To achieve this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, but he admits he is never certain about the final outcome. He explains, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start with yellow, knowing what I will add on top." Like many talented artists, Aitchison makes it seem simple. He believes, "Anyone can use the colors - you can buy them. I just pay attention to what colors are next to each other."

Unlike some artists, Aitchison does not create sketches before starting a painting. He feels that making sketches might make him lose interest in the actual painting. Instead, he often changes his paintings multiple times before they are complete. This is why he prefers to work with models who do not ask to see their portraits while he is painting. He says, "If I sense they are anxious and want to look at the painting, I can't continue."

Since moving to London, Aitchison has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He claims he is not interested in following any artistic tradition; he simply paints in his own way. Nevertheless, his work continues to inspire young British artists.

**Rock Band**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against it because we were worried about the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing video games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." Eventually, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you need to think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. Now, for several hours each week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit unusual, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't judge their musical talent—after all, I didn't expect my parents to enjoy the same music I liked as a teenager—but they do perform regularly in local clubs for young people. 

Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but that hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is clear: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. This college offers students valuable experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to prepare for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from various countries, study in the mornings. In the afternoons, they participate in meaningful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best aspects of Atlantic College is its diverse student body, which includes individuals from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the tuition fees are £20,000 for two years, many students rely on grants to attend. About 25% of the students are British, and many of them can only go to the college with government support.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you may not like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed that I argued much less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education through effective methods that truly benefit its students.

**Being an Older Student**

At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. Along with attending lectures regularly, I have had to learn to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job did not challenge me. I became increasingly unhappy with the idea of being stuck in that job. I envied the students at the local university, who seemed happy, carefree, and full of hope, and I wanted to be part of that experience.

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I am grateful for this chance to study because I understand that having a qualification is important for getting a good job, which matters a lot to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends studying rather than going out to parties. I also enjoy the typical student benefits, like long holidays and discounts for theaters and cinemas.

I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in my life is a smart decision.

**Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born in 1863 on a farm in Michigan, but he did not enjoy farming. At the age of fifteen, he started working as a mechanic, and in 1893, he created his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and then built two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong yet lightweight steel, he produced affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model 'T', which was priced at $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

**Rebecca Stevens**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before this achievement, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca decided to leave her job and family to travel to Asia with a group of climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very challenging. She said, "You must carry everything on your back, so you can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even bring a toothbrush. I usually like to stay clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the summit of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the happiest moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. She has since written a book about her journey, and people often invite her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. Although Rebecca is now well-known and has more money, she still lives in her small flat in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains.

**CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds would not survive if they stayed there. 

Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. These young birds had lost their parents. Bill realized that they would not know how to migrate in the autumn. He owned a small plane and decided to teach the geese to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese followed him.

When autumn arrived and the weather turned cold, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. After reaching Virginia, Bill left the geese there and returned home.

This spring, Bill waited for the geese to come back, but they did not arrive. Concerned, he flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not locate them. When he returned home, he was surprised to find the geese waiting for him. They had managed to find their way back home on their own!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, she decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 per jar to her friends and quickly doubled her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents were not supportive of her decision. They wanted her to focus on studying and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther ignored their advice and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked.

After two years, her business had grown significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She produced various types of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire some employees to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens, selling milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each one produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them comfortable.

Five years ago, Jenny tried to sell sweaters made from the wool at country markets, but it was summer and too hot for people to buy sweaters. Instead, she made socks, which became very popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began. Initially, she made the socks at home, but soon she gained thousands of customers, so she had to send the wool to a factory where machines now produce all the socks.

The socks come in six colors and five sizes, suitable for all ages, and there are different types for walkers, athletes, and skiers. Jenny is especially busy during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, she has many letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

**BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON**

According to the police, most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that the number of burglaries has increased by over 30% compared to last year. He noted that 67% of these crimes happen when people leave their homes and forget to close doors or windows. 

Inspector Saunders mentioned that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home during that time. However, winter afternoons are particularly favorable for burglars since it gets dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Many houses are also empty during this time because people are still at work.

To help prevent burglaries, Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when going on holiday. This can deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to keep an eye on each other's homes when someone is away and to call the police if they notice anything suspicious. 

"We can also provide advice on how to make your home safer," Inspector Saunders said. "This assistance is free of charge."

**The History of Farming**

Before farming began, people searched forests for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started to grow their own food. These individuals were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, leading to the growth of larger villages. As a result, some villagers could focus on other jobs, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming could be challenging, especially during bad weather, which sometimes left people without enough food. Today, farmers can produce more food, which can travel thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.

**WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

The Weather People study the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various professions. For instance, weather significantly affects farmers. In the past, farmers would spend a lot of time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Nowadays, there are many computer programs that help us predict the weather, and people can access weather information on their mobile phones. Despite this, many people still hold onto traditional beliefs about the weather. For example, some say that a red sky in the evening means it will be sunny the next day, and others believe that if cows lie down in the fields, rain is coming soon.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework; instead, they have created a new computer word game.

The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who struggles with reading. Kevin finds it easier to learn words by seeing pictures and hearing sounds rather than by reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Together, Frazer and Peter dedicated over 200 hours to develop this computer game, which is now ready to use. 

The game combines speaking and pictures. For instance, when you see the word "hat," there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying "Hat! Hat!" at the same time. The boys have received many awards for their game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in purchasing it.

**How Does the Irish Pop Group 'Boyzone' Live a Healthy Life?**

Getting enough sleep is very important. When I return to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, I find it hard to sleep because my mind is filled with music. 

Sports are also important. Before my car accident, I used to spend two and a half hours a day at the sports center, five days a week. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups each day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke, and I try to eat healthily. I also drink a lot of water because it is good for your health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don’t always manage that.

People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I like to listen to music or watch TV. It is beneficial to relax sometimes. Since the doctor advised me to eat better, I no longer feel tired. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day, but I still enjoy burgers occasionally!

**Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India, and it produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, far surpassing the USA. Watching films is the most popular leisure activity for many Indians, with around ten million people going to the cinema every day. 

Bollywood films often focus on romantic love stories, and they include a lot of singing and dancing. These films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors produce more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films have a production cost of about $2 million, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million to make.

Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but their careers are often short. Amitabh Bachchan, who is considered by some to be India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films over a career that has lasted almost 40 years.

Bill Bryson

I was born in the United States, but I have written many travel books about England. I lived there with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have been back in the United States. Our children are now experiencing life here, and I believe they will be happier because they have lived in two different countries. I enjoy Britain and want to return, but my daughter, Felicity, is starting college here soon, so it will be another four years before we go back.

Recently, I spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to promote my new book. Many writers dislike this part of the job; they don’t enjoy traveling around to sell their books. However, I don’t mind it. I like exploring new places and meeting many people. This experience is very different from my writing life in the United States. In England, I was driven around in large cars and stayed in nice hotels. It was great because I didn’t have to pay for anything. Everyone was friendly, and I had a lot of fun.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes arrived in England over 50 years ago, while the Giant Schnauzer is a more recent addition. The name "Giant" is fitting because these dogs stand between 65 and 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular grooming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is typically black. 

Schnauzers originate from Germany, where they assist farmers with sheep herding. They are also used by the police due to their high intelligence. Schnauzers make great family pets; they are friendly and get along well with young children.

The Ruwenzori Mountains

Mary Daniels is a student from England. This year, she had a fascinating summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. Their purpose was to help build a road through a forest that connects two large towns. 

Mary described the experience as very challenging because there was no drinking water and no shops to buy food. She also mentioned that it was very cold and rainy in the mountains, which are known to be one of the wettest places in the world. 

Mary spent six weeks in the mountains. Although the work was tough, she believes it was the best experience of her life. She hopes to return next year to continue her work there.

The History of Horse Racing

Horse racing has been an important sport since the earliest history books were written. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started in the 12th century when Arab horses were brought to Europe. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses, but this changed at the start of the 18th century. Races became shorter and included multiple horses competing against each other. Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball, and it is also very popular in many other parts of the world.

Nick Barlow is a world traveler and a British actor who enjoys his job. He travels globally to create TV shows. "People are friendly to me wherever I go, and when I return home, I think about all the amazing experiences I've had in different countries," he shares. Although Nick has visited many places, he still wants to travel to South America and return to Australia someday.

On his trips, Nick works with a team that brings cameras and other equipment for filming. He doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always includes some books in his suitcase. His wife, Helen, supports his travels for work. She has many friends and stays busy while he is away. When he returns, she enjoys hearing about his adventures.

However, there can be challenges. While in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick learned that his wife was in the hospital. "I felt awful because I couldn't be there to help her, but she insisted that I stay. I was so relieved when I found out she was better."

**Parrots**

You may have seen these beautiful birds with their vibrant colors and long tails in forests or zoos. Parrots are found in countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They typically live in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many different species of parrots, but all of them have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold food. The largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are quite noisy, but they are intelligent and can be taught to talk easily. Some zoos even have parrot shows where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village located about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there around three and a half months ago. Although not many people in Britain know his name yet, he is already quite well-known in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about many of the best restaurants in the country. At just 29 years old, Howard has a passion for food. 

As a teenager, he often visited restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed these experiences so much that he chose to spend his money on trips to France and dining at fine restaurants instead of buying clothes and CDs. He also collected many cookbooks, claiming to have over two hundred and fifty! 

So, why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply put, he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He admits that starting a restaurant is expensive and that cooking for fifty people is much harder than cooking for his family. However, he believes he has made the right choice.

In a small town in central England, John Pickering mows the grass and waters the flowers in a park. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television because he is currently the top singer in Japan. A few months ago, John traveled to Japan to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey discovered his songs and played them on his radio show. Many young listeners called in, asking the disc jockey to play his songs again. John, who goes by the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, plans to continue his job in the park in England. He is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I need to keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have bills to pay!" The other gardeners are unaware of his fame in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This won't change our lifestyle. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

**Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. In nearly every town, you can find clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is simple to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to meet new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began around fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

The Rhino

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types are found in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino's body rests on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and their diet consists mainly of grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos at birth and stays in its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilos and may live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, we see police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few elderly men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid well. Around 300 years ago, London was growing larger. The city was very dirty, and many people lived in poverty. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, which made people stay at home as much as possible.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of individuals to catch thieves. They were similar to police officers and were called the 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had expanded significantly and needed more police.

So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was established with 3,000 officers. Most of these men patrolled on foot, while a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid quite well, and those who still ride horses earn even higher salaries than their colleagues.

Text: 'Experience the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with actors and artists from around the world. They come to participate in the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are vibrant with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists create paintings on the streets. A highlight of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. **ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming beneath the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

To fish, you first break the ice and make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and lower it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people enjoy eating them, but after I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a fun sport, and you can meet nice people here!

Madame Tussaud's

One well-known tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Visitors can see wax figures of many famous people there. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him with this work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures are still on display today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were quite expensive, and only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early models looked very different from modern bicycles. Over time, as prices decreased, more people began to buy bicycles. They started using them for commuting and leisure activities. 

Today, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to cycle to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it difficult to find parking.

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went directly to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers would give a new brush filled with paint to each elephant and take away the old one. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they no longer do that, but the smartest elephants live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it’s hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These groups often work together to hunt for food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats rely on their excellent eyesight to catch smaller prey. They also need to be fast and strong.

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilograms. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are decreasing. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. Instead, they use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches are very fast runners, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around three years to grow into adults. They primarily eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Snowboarding

Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has achieved success in many competitions. We spoke to her last week at a snowboarding event in Switzerland and asked her why she chose this sport. She said, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months."

We also inquired about her practice routine. She explained, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I truly enjoy all of it! I love the competitions and being in the mountains; it’s so beautiful. However, free-riding—doing what you want outside of competitions—is the best part for me."

Finally, we asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She replied, "You can learn quickly, but taking lessons is essential. Having the right clothing is also important to stay dry, especially since you will fall a lot at first!"

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man, have successfully climbed it. There are several routes to reach the summit, and the Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. This route usually takes about five days and is very popular among tourists. However, only half of those who attempt to climb Kilimanjaro actually reach the top. This is often due to the unpredictable weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but as climbers approach the summit, they encounter ice and snow, with temperatures dropping below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should pack both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were so polluted that many fish and insects died, leaving otters without food. However, today the rivers are clean again, and there is plenty of food for them.

People have always created buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. 

Many people collaborate on a building project. The architect designs how the building will look and creates drawings to share their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Finally, workers carefully construct it.

The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a stunning roof. However, it is beautiful from all angles, not just the top. Another famous structure is the Olympic Stadium in Munich, which has a unique roof that resembles a glass tent.
